characters: INT, DAY ROOM IN FRENCH BARRACKS
OUTSKIRTS SMALL TOWN IN CENTRAL SICILY
EXT, LAWN OF VILLA IN CORSICA, (AJACCIO)
EXT, A ROAD OUT OF CATANIA, (EAST COAST OF SICILY)
INT, II CORPS COMMANDING GENERAL'S OFFICE
EXT, U.S. II CORPS HEADQUARTERS, DJEBEL KOUIF TOWN SQUARE
EXT, C-47 AIRPLANE IN FLIGHT OVER CHANNEL
AIR VICE MARSHAL SIR ARTHUR CONINGHAM AND LIEUTENANT
TANK COMMANDER IN TURRET OF MOVING TANK
CHIEF OF STAFF TO GENERAL EISENHOWER

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Our entire frame is filled with the image of an American flag, stretched tight. We hear a jumble of conversation in the b.g.3; then:

dialogues.speaker: _ VOICE
dialogues.text: {o.s.) At-ten-shun! Now we hear the click of hundreds of boots. GENERAL GEORGE S. PATTON, JR. steps into our view; more than six feet tall, he looms high against the b.g. of the flag. He glares down at us, the audience. A MILITARY BAND plays THE STAR SPANGLED BANNER, Patton comes to a smart salute, and we watch him for the dura- tion of the entire anthem. He is straight and husky and as gaudy as a peacock. His helmet is lacquered and shines with four silver stars. He wears a tailored tunic, with four stars on each shoulder, thirty brightly hued decorations on the left breast, five horizontal and three diagonal gold stripes on the sleeve. Beneath the tunic, he wears a shirt with four stars on each lapel, making a total of twenty stars. A vivid blue sash is draped across his breast, parallel to one of yellow, A red collar sash weighted by another medal hangs from his neck The rest of his costume consists of a gold-buckled belt, with his ivory-handled pistols on either side, riding breeches, boots, and a riding crop. Four stars on the handle of his pistols brings the grand total to twenty- eight stars. On his fingers he wears four conspicuous rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the anthem continues, we cut to a series of tight shots featuring various aspects of Patton's uniform and decorations -- emphasizing the clusters of stars on his shoulders, his shirt, his pistols.  66

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The anthem concludes and he completes his salute. Now this twenty-eight-star general scans us carefully. In & vibrant voice, and with a cold, mean look, he speaks directly at us:

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: At ease, men. I want you to remember that no bastard ever won a war by dying for his country, He won it by making the other poor dumb bastard die for his country... Men, the stuff we heard about America not wanting to fight, wanting to stay out of the war, was a lot of horsedung. Americans traditionally love to fight. All real Americans love the sting of battle. When you were kids you all admired the champion marble player, the fastest runner, the big league ballplayers, the toughest boxers. Americans love a . Winner and do not tolerate a loser. Americans play to win all the time. I wouldn't give a hoot in hell for a man who lost and laughed. That's why Americans have never lost, and will never lose a war, for the very thought of losing is hateful to Americans, An army is a team. It lives, sleeps, eats, fights as a team. This individu- ality stuff is a lot of crap. The bilious bastards who wrote that stuff about individuality for the Saturday Evening Post don't know any more about real battle than they do about a sock full of silt. We have the finest food, equipment, the best spirit and men in the world. Why, by God, I actually pity those poor bastards we're going against -- by God, I do, We won't just shoot the bastards. We're going to cut out their living guts and use them to grease the treads of our tanks. We're going to murder those lousy Hun bastards by the bushel. Many of you boys are wondering whether you'll chicken out under fire. Don't worry about it; I can assure you you will all do your duty. The Nazis are the enemy. Wade into them and spill their blood, Shoot them in the belly. When you stick your hand into a bunch of goo that a moment before was your best friend's face...you'li know what to Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 9 Cont. 10 PATTON (Cont. ) do. There's another thing I want you to remember. I don't want to get any messages saying: 'We are holding our position.' We're not holding anything. Let the Hun do that. We are advancing constantly and are not interested in holding anything, except onto the enemy. We're going to hold onto him by the nose and kick him in the ass. We'll kick the hell out of him all the time. We'll go through them like crap through a goose. pause) There's one thing you men will be able to say when you get home. You may all thank God for it, Thirty years from now, when you are sitting around the fireside with your grandson on your knee and he asks what you did in the great World War II, you won't have to say, 'I shoveled shit in Louvisiana.' (pause) All right -- now you sonsuvbitches kmow how I feel. I will be proud to lead you wonderful guys into battle anytime, anywhere He stares sincerely, almost wet-eyed at us for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: That is all. —_—

dialogues.speaker: FEBRUARY, 1943
dialogues.text: We view the enormous sloping desert, baking hot in the midday sun. Tanks, half-tracks and self-propelled artillery are spread about in the distance. Scattered over the hot sands are the bodies of dead Americans, Arab women and children, dressed in brightly colored costumes, scavenge the uniforms, boots and equipment and pack them on heavily laden cameis.  a 5 66 il 12

dialogues.speaker: ARAB WOMEN
dialogues.text: One woman, an infant strapped to her back and a small child helping her, strips a soldier totally naked and hurries the precious belongings to the camel pack. The women work quickly and silently; there are no games, no joking, no playing with the treasure. We hear the sound of motor vehicles approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimmering in the rising heat waves, two jeeps come into scene and pull up to a halt. In the rear are two American generals and, beside the Driver, a Captain who carries Cont.  12 Cont. 13 14 15 16 a submachine gun. The Major General carries a Springfield '03 rifle across his lap. In the other jeep is Bradley's Second Aide, who carries a bazooka. The Captain fires a burst of his submachine gun into the air to frighten off the Arab women, and they scurry toward their camels.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR GENERAL
dialogues.text: He shields his eyes from the sun as he rises to study the battlefield grimly. He is a tall, lanky, gentle-looking man. His face has great strength, but his eyes reflect wisdom and understanding.

dialogues.speaker: REPRESENTATIVE OF GENERAL EISENHOWER
dialogues.text: (NOTE: Bradley will carry @ Springfield in Africa, a carbine in Sicily and a .45 in Europe.)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: He is a man in his mid-twenties. He, too, is affected by the scene of carnage.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR P.0.V.
dialogues.text: As the camera pans across the bitter scene, the Arab women melt into the arid folds of the desert.

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF COMMAND CAR
dialogues.text: Beside Bradley is BRIGADIER GENERAL CARVER. {Fictitious character -- no subtitle.) Since he participated in the debacle, he is diffident about commenting on it -- especially to a representative of General Eisenhower.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: The Arabs need food and clothing. They strip our dead before we can even bury them. .

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (studying the scene) Looks like the reports were accurate.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: (consulting a pad) Sixty-one armored vehicles -- forty- five tons of ammunition -- twenty- five 40mm guns -- three self-propelled 105s. Not counting mortars, machine guns, rifles, pistols, telescopes, belt buckles, GI socks. Cont.  66 16 Cont. 17 18 19 20 CARVER (Cont. ) (uneasily) And one thousand eight hundred men. Bradley's gaze goes back to the silent battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: THE BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: Camera explores the stark horror of the silent, deserted killing ground.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: The exotically caparisoned mounted Drummer filis the screen as he beats his two huge instruments with a flourish. Visually as well as auditorially, this is in sharpest contrast to the preceding scene. A military band of about one hundred pieces is blaring out a martial air. Camera pulls back to reveal the entire mounted band of a@ Moroccan regiment of Chasseurs-a-Cheval, with their sheep mascot and bell-covered umbrella. Lined up behind the band is the regiment, in scarlet uniforms, white capes and turbans.

dialogues.speaker: REVIEWING STAND
dialogues.text: The colorfully garbed SULTAN addresses General Patton, whose uniform and decorations are only slightly less bizarre than those about him.

dialogues.speaker: SULTAN
dialogues.text: My people salute you, General -- for your brilliant amphibious landing on the continent of Africa -- and for your enlightened administration of my country.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I've enjoyed being here, Your Excellency. But naturally I'd prefer to be up at the front in Tunisia fighting Germans. The Sultan nods, places the ribbon of a large disc-shaped decoration around Patton's neck,

dialogues.speaker: SULTAN
dialogues.text: (reading inscription) 'The lions in their dens tremble at his approach', Cont.  20 Cont. al 22 23 a4 25 26 Patton glances down, eyes the decoration.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with genuine pride) I appreciate that, Your Excellency. There is a fanfare from the band and they turn to watch.

dialogues.speaker: PARADE GROUND
dialogues.text: Playing a stirring march review, followed by the

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND S
dialogues.text: » the band moves out to pass in colorful Chasseurs,

dialogues.speaker: ULTAN
dialogues.text: With Patton's party is LIEUTENANT COLONEL HENRY DAVENPORS (fictitious character -- no subtitle). At Patton's side is his Aide, CAPWAIN RICHARD N. JENSON. Patton is both fascinated and impressed by the color and the pageantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the parade ground, a battalion of French territorial infantry in white uniforms passes in review, followed by Moroccan infantry with + are bristling with excit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strutting commander battalion of Legionnaire red epaulets,

dialogues.speaker: PARADE GROUN
dialogues.text: The Legion contingent is dressed units -- French with flowing capes. The man carries a huge knife suggest the romantic mil he red Fourragere, The streets ed spectators. of the Foreign Legion, leading a s in traditional white caps and iD followed by other exotically Senegalese, Goums on horseback y are fierce-looking and each - These French colonial troops itary splendor of the past.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND JENSON
dialogues.text: Patton is clearly moved. This is his dish of tea. Cont,  26 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (fervently) Magnificent! (to Jenson) I wish our troops looked like that! He and the Sultan return the salute of the unit passing.

dialogues.speaker: SULTAN
dialogues.text: Tell me, General what do you think of Marrakech?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I love it, Your Excellency. It's a combination of Hollywood and the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, GERMAN POW ENCLOSURE
dialogues.text: Camera moves, with barbed wire fence in f.g., along the outside of the POW cage, picking up the faces of the American prisoners inside. They are a grim, bearded, dirty and dejected lot. Camera picks up an immaculate Africa Corps staff COLONEL striding along outside the wire carrying a briefcase. We follow him as he crosses to a command car in which is seated a German Field Marshal, surrounded by aides and staff officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROMMEL, goggles on chest, is studying a map on which an officer is pointing out dispositions.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER, AFRICA CORPS
dialogues.text: The staff Colonel comes into scene, presents himself to Rommel.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! He gets no response from Rommel,

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: You wanted to see the interrogation reports on the American prisoners captured in our victory at Kasserine, Field Marshal. (he bands the briefcase to Rommel's aide) They are not very good soldiers, these Americans. Unimpressed, Rommel is incisive, thoughtful. He gives the Colonel a sharp giance. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be so sure after one battle. Their tanks were no match for our guns.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: One could say the same, sir, for their leadership. Rommel eyes the Colonel evenly. He's not that easily flattered. .

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: They were not under American command at Kasserine. They were under British General Anderson -- did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (undaunted, he smiles) British commanders and American troops. They had the worst of everything!

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: I remind you that Montgomery is a British commander. And he has driven us halfway across Africa.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: In any case, we have met the Americans for the first time and defeated them... Personally, I feel extremely optimistic. Rommel eyes him with dry disdain.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: You can afford to be an optimist. I can't.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The jeep bearing Bradley, Carver and Hansen drives up in front of the headquarters. Lounging dejectedly outside is a group of unkempt GIs, Bearded and unsoldierly, they Straggle to their feet, some managing a ragged salute. It is clearly e unit without discipline or morale, a unit that's suffered defeat. Bradley and Carver return the salutes as they step out of the jeep. Bradley studies the soldiers closely as the jeep pulls away and Hansen goes on inside.  66 28

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (quietly, as he eyes the soldiers) These men fight at Kasserine?

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: (uneasily) Yes, sir. Bradley moves to go inside, changes his mind, turns to Carver, asking for frankness.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: John, General Eisenhower sent me down here to make a report and I've got to lay it on the line. What went wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: Everything. Second-rate ta -- bad intelligence -- green troops... So green some of the boys marked our mine fields for their own protection and forgot to take the flags down.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (eyeing him shrewdly) Green commanders, too?

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: For the American Army to take a licking like that our first time at bat against the Germans -- (he shakes his head) Up against Rommel we need the best tank man we've got. Somebody tough enough to pull this outfit together.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: (with a quick, apprehensive glance) George Patton?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (enigmatic) Possibly --

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: God help us.  66 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the distant apparition of a chain of military vehicles kicking up the dust as it speeds along the desert, silhouetted before a great rising rosy sun. A siren wails, coming out of nowhere and growing louder and louder, until the half-track, with banners flying and machine guns fore and aft, comes at us as ostenta~ tiously as a fire engine.  66 30 31 32 33 34 35 36 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Patton, in a bulky trench coat, stands upright in the armored car, his face grimacing into the wind, a Caesar in his chariot.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, DJEBEL KOUIF TOWN SQUARE
dialogues.text: The caravan roars into the decrepit square opposite the schoolhouse that serves as II Corps Headquarters. Arabs scurry through the streets in the midst of & cackling exodus of camels and chickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caravan comes to a halt before the schoolhouse where a single SENTRY stands sloppily at his post. Patton steps over the side of his car, followed by a Lieutenant and a Captain. Patton regards the town square and the scruffy-looking soldiers lounging in it, his face frozen in the same expression as when it was blown by the wind. PATTON'S P.O.V. Groups of unshaven GIs, wearing sweaters and field Jacket yawning and indescribably slack, pyll themselves to their feet. Most of them manage a ragged series of salutes. Others simply watch with mild curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: His jaw tightens, his eyes begin to flash.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN AND LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: They eye the General apprehensively. Jenson is a young man, STILLER in his mid-forties.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Eyes flashing, rage barely under control, he draws him- self up and snaps off an ultrasmart salute to the ragged crew, Turning on his heel, he passes a crudely built Sign designating II Corps Headquarters, on which a chicke squats. Nearby an Arab peddler leans, unimpressed, agains a pen of chickens.  —_ 37 38 39 66 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sentry, without tie and needing a shave, pulls him- self to attention as Patton approaches. The man manages a salute, then stares at Patton with a sleck-jawed and not unfriendly smile. Patton's eyes widen. Incapable of speech, there issues from within. him a volcanic rumble that is almost a retch Failing to return the man's salute, he strides into the building.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Sentry, .where's the Duty Officer?

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Sir, I don!t rightly know.

dialogues.speaker: . JENSON
dialogues.text: Is he in the building?

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm under the impression he is not. Visibly irritated, Jenson goes on into the building, following Stiller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenson follows Stiller down the corridor, which is quite dark because the blackout curtains have not yet been pulled open. Patton can be seen down the corridor, opening doors, glancing inside, slamming them shut again, He opens a map room door and steps inside, followed by Stiller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated in the map room is a young SECOND’ LIEUTENANT, smiling contentedly, his feet up on a table, reading ae magazine. Seeing Patton and Stiller, he nervously hops to attention.

dialogues.speaker: STILLER
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (flustered) Well, sir, I -- I'm on Map Room duty, sir,

dialogues.speaker: STILLER
dialogues.text: That your map? Cont.  66 12 39 Cont. 4o 41

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (tossing magazine aside No, sir -- it's definitely not amap, sir. Patton turns and strides out, followed by Stiller.

dialogues.speaker: INT, ANOTHER OFFICE
dialogues.text: as Jenson enters. There are several desks in the make- shift office, at one of which sits a sleeping LIEUTENANT. A SERGEANT concentrates intently on a solitaire layout. Patton and Stiller appear in the corridor outside, pause to overhear the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant pops upright, pulls himself to his feet. The Sergeant merely looks up; he's seen a lot of captains

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: (sternly) Where's the Duty Officer?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Sir, he -- I think he's at his quarters, shaving.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Why isn't he here on duty?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: I guess he needed a shave. (grinning) We've got a new commanding general due in today. Patton appears in the doorway, his face looking like a storm at sea. The Lieutenant instantly loses his grin. He hits a rigid attention, yells at the card-playing Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: (frenziedly) Forbes! Snap to! Patton turns on his heel with a growl of rage and disappe

dialogues.speaker: INT, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: He angrily moves down the dark corridor. We move faster and faster to keep up with him, until there is a dull clunk and Patton practically falls flat on his face. We hear a groan and then: Cont.  43 41 Cont. 42 43

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Who the hell's kicking me in the butt! A PRIVATE, who had been curled asleep on the corridor flo rises, about to punch whomever it was in the nose, when h realizes that he is face to face with General Patton.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: (coming to a salute) Oh! Sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: What were you doing down there, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: (decisively) Trying to get some sleep, sir. PATTON. Well, get the hell back down there, son. You're the only sonuvabitch in this headquarters who knows what he's trying to do!

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: INT, STAIRWAY AND SECOND-FLOOR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Someone pulls aside heavy blackout curtains, letting in some light. SERGEANT WILLIAM GEORGE MEEKS, Patton's Negro orderly, and a coupie of other enlisted men carry the General's personal gear -- a footlocker marked with his name and rank, etc. -- up the stairs, Patton himself passes these bearers on his way upstairs, is met by Stiller as he reaches the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: STILLER
dialogues.text: General Bradley's waiting in your office, sir. (pointing to an office) Down at the end of the hall. Patton and Stiller move off down the hall as, unseen by them, a couple of enlisted men carry by us a footlocker marked MAJOR GENERAL LLOYD R. FREDENDALL.

dialogues.speaker: INT, II CORPS COMMANDING GENERAL'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The spacious room is bare and depersonalized, having been just vacated. Bradley stands at a window, waiting. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: } 43 Cont. (o.2.) PATTON'S VOICE O68. Brad! How the hell are you! Patton comes into scene and the two men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Fine, George. Good to see you. (checking his watch) We were all under the impression that you wouldn't be here until 0900.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I gathered that. You lmow my boys, don't you? Dick Jenson and Al Stiller. Bradley nods with a smile.. Patton plants himself behind the desk, lights a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Tell me, Brad -- what are you doing here? a BRADLEY Ike wanted a report on this Kasserine setback. Meanwhile, I'm supposed to stay here in your headquarters -- as an observer -- but I report directly to Ike. His ‘eyes and ears' was the way he put it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (grinning) I see - a spy! (turning to Jenson) Get me General Eisenhower's headquarters. Jenson picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: (into phone) Allied Force Headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What really went wrong at Kasserine? I've only seen the preliminary report.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Apparently everything went wrong. We'd send over a 75mm shell, the Krauts would return an 68, Their tanks are diesels -- even when we managed to hit them they kept running. The men call our tanks 'Purple Heart Boxes.' One hot piece of shrapnel 66 and the gasoline explodes. ww Cont.  15 43 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: T warned them about the tanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: I talked to one soldier about the half-tracks. Asked him if machine- gun fire pierced the armor. He said, 'No, sir -- the bullets only come in one side and rattle around a bit.!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I hear we had trouble coordinating the air cover.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: The trouble was no air cover.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: (handing him telephone ) General Smith on the line, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (into phone) Beetle, I'm calling about Bradley and his job here... Look, I need @ good number two man. I want to make Brad my deputy commander... Okay? You clear it with Ike. He hangs up, takes a mean puff of his cigar, scowls up at Bradley shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Now you're not spying for Ike anymore -- you're working for me. (challenging) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Fine. Patton turns to Jenson.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Dick -- you got those stars?

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: (with a grin) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Well, let's get 'em on. Cont. 66  16 43 Cont.2 Jenson produces a handful of shiny three-star collar pieces. Patton sits down behind the big desk as Stiller on one side and Jenson on the other start to pin on the new insignia. An expression of doubt flashes across Bradley's face; Patton notices it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Hell, I've been nominated by the President.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: But it isn't official until it's approved by the Senate.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (grinning) Well -- they have their schedule end I have mine.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (watching the aides work) George, if you were named Admiral of the Turkish Navy, I'll bet your @ides could dip into their haversacks and come up with the appropriate badge of rank, . (with a grin) Anyway -- premature congratulations. Their ceremonial duties over, Stiller goes out and Jensén busies himself arranging a desk for himself. Patton rises and crosses to a mirror to inspect his new rank. Bradley crosses to the window.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Those stars would look a lot better on a green shirt... Did I ever tell you I once designed a uniform for tank crewmen? It was green leather with red stripes, sort of a row of brass buttons here and topped by a gold football helmet. (wistfully) The Army rejected it. But damn, it was beautiful. Camera moves in on Bradley at the window, looking down into the street below. Ane our . 45 ~—  46 47 4g. 50 51 17 BRADLEY'S P.0.V. GENERAL FREDENDALL, in a jeep with a driver and one aide, is saying good-bye to a couple of his staff officers. It is obviously a dispirited and uncomfortable farewell.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Bradley indicates the street below to explain what he's been looking at.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Lloyd Fredendall's just leaving. Patton crosses to the window. out

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TOWN SQUARE
dialogues.text: Fredendall's jeep barrels out of the square and disappear Camera pans to Patton's command car, where two drivers ar replacing a huge two-star plate with a huge three-star plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley and Patton are still watching down below. Bradley turns to Patton.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George, there's one other thing I put in my Kasserine report. Some of our boys were just plain scared.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: They'1l get over that. Even the best foxhounds are gun-shy the first time out. I can remember when nothing scared me worse than the idea of a bullet coming straight for my nose. I don't know why, but somehow the idea of getting it straight in the nose was just more horrible than any other possibility.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (a wry smile) I can understand that, George, with such a handsome nose. Cont.  wy 66 52 Cont. 18

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (relighting his cigar; he pulls on it fiercely) You want to know why this outfit got the hell kicked out of it? A blind man could see it in five minutes! They don't look like soldiers -- they don't act like soldiers -- why should they fight like soldiers?!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: No question about it -- the discipline's pretty poor.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) Starting in fifteen minutes, we're going to turn these boys into razor- sharp fanatics. (Vesuvius preparing to erupt) . These men may lose their fear of Germans, but by God they'11 never lose their fear of me!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton and Jenson cross the square on their way to the officers' mess hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few sleepy OFFICERS have begun to straggle in as Patton enters, with Jenson in tow. A cheerful COOK approaches.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Up bright and early, General. Breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Am I to understand that my officers have all finished their breakfast? cook We're open from six to eight. Most of the officers are just coming in, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (indicating officers entering) Inform these officers that the mess hall is closed. Cont.  66 19 54 Cont. 55 56 cook But, sir, it's only a quarter to eight.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: After this, you open at six o'clock and no one is admitted after six- fifteen...Where are your leggings? cook (startled) Leggings? Hell, General, sir, I'm a cook.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You're a soldier! (over his shoulder, to Jenson) A twenty dollar fine. Scowling, Patton turns away from the flabbergasted Cook to the others present.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You all heard me. Beginning now, men without leggings or helmets or ties - men with unshined shoes and soiled uniforms -- are going to get skinned for it!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND JENSON
dialogues.text: Panning with them as they move away, Patton growling to ~ Jenson quietly.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Hit ‘em in the pocketbook and they'll remember.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: This is a large room that's been converted into enlisted men's quarters, with rows of bunks, combat gear, etc. As Patton, accompanied by Jenson, sweeps through the empty room, his eye falls on a pinup tacked to the wall. We get a glimpse of a raw, provocative pose of an enormously bosomed girl. Patton pauses, his Puritan outrage unmistakable.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: This is a barracks -- not a bordello! He tears the picture off the wall, balls it up and throws it down sternly. Then he marches out,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera follows Patton in f.g. as, in going from squad room to town square, he happens to pass a row of canvas stalls, followed by Jenson, Seated in each stall is a soldier, revealed from the neck up. Patton speaks curtly as he passes the first stall. The soldier inside is hat- less.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No helmet -- twenty dollars. {passing tha second stall) No helmet and no leggings -- twenty-five dollars. He crosses to the third stall where a very young and sharply turned-out GI sits at attention, a polished helmet on his head. He looks straight ahead, but his face wears a vacuous and slightly pained expression appropriate to what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Now that man looks like a soldier!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton and Jenson cross the square to the building being used for a hospital. They are trailed by wide-ayed urchins.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I do not admit the existence of ‘battle fatigue.' Once you concede its reality, you admit the reality of demoralization. And you can't win battles with demoralized troops. That sort of thing has to be stopped or you get ean uncontrollable infection... Like conscientious objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton, followed by Jenson, moves down the aisle of the busy ward, where he is met by a MEDICAL OFFICER. Nurses and other medical personnel (except this medical officer} all wear helmets.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (he's got a head of steam up) I understand you have two cases of self-inflicted wounds.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -- we do. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 58 cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Get them out of here.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sir, one of them's developed a serious infection.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn if he croaks. Get him somewhere else, but out of here. They don't belong in the same Building as boys who've been wounded in battle.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: {acceding without agreeing I'll see that they're moved, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Another thing -- there'll be no "battle fatigue’ in my command... That's an order!

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (growling contemptuously) Battle fatigue is a free ride; a little yellow-belly's ticket to a hospital... I'm not going to subsidize cowardice.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: (eyeing the General blandly) Yes, sir -- Patton has started to turn away, but something in the doctor's tone pulls him back.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Where's your helmet, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: I don't .wear a helmet when I'm in the hospital, General.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {turning to leave) Start. Cont.  (a) Se 66 22 58 cCont.1 59 60

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: (after Patton) I can't use my stethoscope when I'm wearing my helmet...

dialogues.speaker: PATFON
dialogues.text: (realizes he's been challenged ) Then cut two holes in your helmet so you can. AND GET THOSE YELLOW- BELLIES OUT OF HERE TODAY.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, DESERT
dialogues.text: A two-and-a-half-ton truck is parked out on the desert beside the dusty, deserted road. There is nothing else to be seen for miles. Camera moves in on truck, coming to rest as it reveals a SERGEANT reclining in the cab, smoking while he watches a PFC standing beside the cab shaving. The soldier's tin mirror and helmet full of water rest on the hood of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: You know what's so important in the back of this truck? Preoccupied with shaving, the Pfc shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: . Shoe polish.

dialogues.speaker: PFC
dialogues.text: Shoe polish?!

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Georgie Patton is a nut about spit and polish. If I let you turn up at his headquarters without a shave, you'd get a month in the stockade. There is the sound cf an approaching vehicle, then the insistent honking of a horn. The Sergeant, irritated, sticks his hand out of the cab, without looking, and motions the other vehicle ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Come ahead, you silly bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealing a jeep as it drives up alongside the soldier shaving. Beside the SERGEANT DRIVER (Bradley's driver) the jeep contains a three-star and a two-star general -- Cont.  23 60 Cont. Patton and Bradley. The shaving soldier gulps, faced suddenly with all that brass. He shifts his razor awkwardly, manages a salute.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: frowning sternly) What's in that helmet, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: PFC
dialogues.text: Water, sir -- (helplessly indicating Sergeant) He told me to shave.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: need I want your head in that helmet -- not water! With the back of his hand, Patton sweeps the helmet off the hood of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: oO Now pick it up and wear it! As the PFC retrieves his helmet, Patton gestures to his driver and the jeep roars on out of scene. The PFC is. stunned by this general who materializes out in the deser and disappears in a matter of seconds.

dialogues.speaker: PFC
dialogues.text: (to Sergeant) You told me he wanted everybody to shave.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: I also told you he was a nut!

dialogues.speaker: MOVING JEEP
dialogues.text: Patton is studying the terrain ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Turn right here, driver.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Sir, the battlefield is straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Don't talk back to me, Sergeant. y I can smell a battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (quietly) George, he was out here just yesterday. BS Cont.  24 OC) 61 Cont. 62 63 64 65 66

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (insistently) It's over there. Turn right, dammit! The Driver makes the turn as ordered.

dialogues.speaker: EXT,
dialogues.text: as the jeep approaches from the distance. -Camera moves along the silent eternal ruins of what was once an aqueduct. The car comes to & stop, Patton, dwarfed by the structure, steps out and looks up at the ancient ruin in awe. The wind makes an eerie sound through the stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley steps out of the car, moves closer to Patton.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (quietly) It was here. The battlefield was here. (pause) The Carthaginians defending the Aqueduct were attacked by three Roman legions. The Carthaginians were proud and brave, but they couldn't hold, Massacre. Arab women stripped them of their tunics, their swords, their lances. The soldiers lay naked in the sun...

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: listening, puzzled, as the strange wind whistles.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (o.s.) .-.two thousand years ago.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I was there, Brad. (with a faint smile) You don't believe me, do you? Bradley doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You know what the poet said -- Cont,  66 65 Cont. 25 PATTON (Cont.) (quoting -- and giving it every- thing) 'Through the travail of ages, Midst the pomp and toils of war, Have I fought and strove and perished countless times upon the star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he listens, studying Patton. 67 TwO SHOT

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) So as through a glass and darkly The age~-long strife I see

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Where I fought in many guises, Many names -- but always me.' (after a suitable pause for effect) You know who the poet was?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with a sudden grin) Me.

dialogues.speaker: DA
dialogues.text: Patton has had the. map room totally revamped and it is now an elaborate and buzzing center of charts and information. COLONEL GASTON BELL (fictitious character - no subtitle), is conducting a briefing for Patton, Bradle Jenson, Stiller, Hansen and several other OFFICERS, using a map.

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: There's an opportunity here for us to mount an cffensive. We have concentrated on harassing the enemy's flank, to draw his strength away from the British. However, it appears now that we could split the Africa Corps and drive through Rommel to the sea.  66 70 ah 26

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (sardonically) Sorry, Bell -- that territory is reserved for General Sir Bernard Law Montgomery. We're supposed to let him win this one -- (sarcastically) -- no matter how long it takes him to do it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: They're entitled to have their hero. After all, Montgomery pushed Rommel clear across North Africa.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What about the Americans? They need a hero, too, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (with a quiet smile) You have anybody in mind, George? Jenson énters.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, Air Vice Marshal Coningham is here with General Buford. Patton rises, dismissing them with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with a grim smile) Excuse me, gentlemen, while I ask our Limey friends what's happened to our air cover. , (as they go) Round one with the British coming up. The officers file out and Jenson enters, escorting

dialogues.speaker: AIR VICE MARSHAL SIR ARTHUR CONINGHAM AND LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: GENERAL HARRY BUFORD (fictitious character - no subtitle)

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND BUFORD
dialogues.text: as the two men greet and shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Harry -- how are you?  rN 72 73 74 66 27

dialogues.speaker: PATTON, BUFORD AND CONINGHAM
dialogues.text: as Patton turns to Coningham.

dialogues.speaker: BUFORD
dialogues.text: George, you know Arthur Coningham --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (sizing up his man as they shake hands) Sir Arthur --

dialogues.speaker: CONINGHAM
dialogues.text: Delighted to see you, General. I've heard so much about you.

dialogues.speaker: BUFORD
dialogues.text: (trying to exercise diplomacy ) It appears, gentlemen, there's been some misunderstanding here, and Ike thought we ought to get things straightened out --

dialogues.speaker: . PATTON
dialogues.text: No misunderstanding at all, Harry. We're supposed to have allied air cover and we don't get it. German Planes have been strafing my troops -~ same as they did to Lloyd Fredendail.

dialogues.speaker: CONINGHAM
dialogues.text: If I may say so, General, I'm afraid your operations reports are inaccurate --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Reports? Three days ago those uts took off after my command car -- ran my ass into a ditch!

dialogues.speaker: CONINGHAM
dialogues.text: stiffly) My staff has assured me we have complete air supremacy everywhere in the Mediterranean. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: When I complained about inadequate air support, you said our troops were ‘not battleworthy'. You spoke about 'the discredited practice of using air force as an alibi for lack of - success on the ground'.., Bad enough . I have to play nursemaid to Montgomery -- I don't have to stand for that!

dialogues.speaker: CONINGHAM
dialogues.text: I sincerely apologize for that remark -- whoever made it. {with a smile) And I promise you one thing, General -- you'll see no more German planes. In that instant, without time even for the raising of Patton's eyebrow, four Heinkel fighter-bombers roar over the building, spattering machine-gun fire. The room rocks, plaster flakes from the ceiling, and the three men flatten themselves on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR
dialogues.text: A satisfied Patton looks over at his. fellow officers, resplendent in their uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You were discussing air supremacy, Sir Arthur -- Just then the windows shatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton is up; Buford goes to the door. Patton looks out the shattered windows. PATTON'S P.0O.V. The four low-flying fighter-bombers strafing the streets. The Arabs run. A herd of camels panics and stampedes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Look at those camels run! Buford tries but can't open the door.

dialogues.speaker: BUFORD
dialogues.text: Damn door won't open. Cont.  79 80 81 82 29 @ 78 Cont. Patton leaps over the window ledging, enthralled by the spectacle of the camel stampede.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Go ahead, you bastards! Take e shot at me! Right in the NOSE!

dialogues.speaker: BUFORD
dialogues.text: Get back in here, George, we need @ corps commander, not a casualty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It soars down, all guns going.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Camels stampeding all around him. From a shoulder holster he draws a pistol, fires at the planes. The fighter- bombers soar off as quickly as they came. Patton peers back at the amazed group of officers. Buford offers his arm to get Patton back into the building. Coningham shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CONINGHAM
dialogues.text: Now how the devil did you ever manage to stage that?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (enormously pleased) If I could find the Nazi sonsuvbitches who flew those planes, I'd mail them each a medal.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The crosses over the graves -- and an occasional Star of David -- are seen as silhouettes in b.g. as Patton and Jenson walk along beside the cemetery on a little rise.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I can't get over how cold the nights are in the desert.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Awfully cold, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Patton walks up the little rise toward camera, pauses to look out into the sparkling, clear desert night.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Rommel's out there some place, waiting for me. Cont.  82 Cont. 30

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I want to fight the champ. If you lose, you've lost to the champ and it's no disgrace. If you win, you're the new champ... If I had my way I'd send that genius sonuvabitch an engraved invitation in iambic pentameter -- a challenge in two stanzas to meet me alone out in the desert.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: I'll deliver it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Rommel in his tank and me in mine. We'd stop at twenty paces, climb out of the turrets and shake hands. Then we'd button up and do battle -- just the two of us. And that battle would decide the outcome of the war. .

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Too bad jousting's gone out of style. It's like your poetry, General -- it isn't part of the Twentieth Century.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe so. The world grew up. Helluva shame... Dick, I want guards posted around this area. If we don't, the damn Arabs'll dig them up to get their uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I want these men taken care of, Our graves mustn't disappear into the sand like all the others who fought here -- the Greeks, the Romans, the Carthaginians. (after a pause; suddenly ) I hate the Twentieth Century! Patton turns and walks away. Jenson, fascinated, watches him go.  66 83 8k 31

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: It is a large room with situation maps of the Russian and North African fronts on the walls, Noncoms make minor adjustments of the front lines and troop dispositions. Young women in uniform - the "Grey Mice" - operate a communications network that keeps the room alive with cold, automated sound. CAPTAIN STEIGER, a junior staff officer whose gentle, studious manner suggests the university rather than the Wehrmacht, makes his way across the bustling room to GENERAL JODL, who studies one of the wall maps, comparing some data he holds in his hand. Jodl is a small, thin, pallid man with a highly nervous manner. (Steiger is fictional - no subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: (presenting himself to Jod1) Captain Oskar Steiger reporting, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Come with me, Steiger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rommel sits behind the desk, a handkerchief to his aching face, suffering an acute and painful attack of nasal diphtheria. Jodl escorts Steiger in.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Field Marshal -- I hope you are feeling better -- Rommel dismisses this with an impatient gesture.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Captain Steiger here is at your disposal. He has been assigned to research the American General Patton.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: Very well. What do you have for me?

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: {consulting notes} General Patton comes of a military family. His grandfather was a hero of the American Civil War. He was educated at the Virginia Military Institute and tiest Point. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: You're not telling me anything about the man.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Sir, he writes poetry and believes in reincarnation. He's one of the richest officers in the American Army. He prays on his knees, but he curses like a stable boy, and he has one standing order: ‘Always take the offensive -- never dig in.'

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Field Marshal -- we see the Fuehrer in fifteen minutes. He will want to lmow what you propose to do about Patton's forces.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: I will attack and annihilate him. (he adds quietly Before he does the same to me.

dialogues.speaker: INT, PATTON'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Meeks and Jenson enter quietly. As Meeks opens the heavy curtains, Jenson moves to a sleeping Patton. A book has fallen on the floor next to him. Jenson picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: The clearly legible title is THE TANK IN WARFARE, by Erwin Rommel

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: General...General...

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (waking) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: Sir, we intercepted a German radio message: Rommel's Tenth Panzer is going to hit us near El Guettar.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (to himself, eagerly) Rommel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groups of camels and Arabs move off in the distance as though intuitively forewarned of the impending battle.  66 89 90 gl 92 93 94 95 96 oT 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the silent, golden desert. Everything is still now.

dialogues.speaker: INT, PATTON'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Sergeant Meeks is dressing Patton with practiced efficien and skill. Neither speaks but there is a certain solemnit recalling years before when warriors prepared for battle. The polished leather belt, the cavalry pants, the boots - all with a quality of ritual -- are placed on Patton.

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY EMPLACEMENTS
dialogues.text: Noncoms wear an air of excitement. The men are tense, waiting. Guns and men are hidden on sides and backs of hill dunes.

dialogues.speaker: INT, PATTON'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Meeks solemnly brushes the uniform and then places the three-star helmet on Patton's head as though he were the Archbishop of Canterbury. Patton can see himself staring back from the mirror. He is frightening.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: All my life I've wanted to lead a@ lot of men in a desperate battle. Now I'm going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: A German scout car appears from a fold in the valley, reconnoitering the area, its commander scanning the terra with binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward the American positions but revealing noth

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT CAR
dialogues.text: The commander lowers his binoculars, speaks into a radio. The scout car turns and disappears into a wadi.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: Bradley's radio-equipped jeep makes it up the tough climb to the command post. The sunlight glint in his spectacles gives him a clear,’deadly seriousness as he joins Hansen and his Second Aide and one or two other officers at the O.P.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PATTON'S OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: perched on the hill. Patton stands in his armored command car, machine guns fore and aft, scanning the terrain with binoculars, Jenson beside him. American tanks can be seen in positions of concealment. Cont,  34 97 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (@ smile of satisfaction) Look. 98 THEIR P.O.V. 99 100 101 102 103 66 In the distance a full battalion of German Infantry march toward the basin in a battle formation that suggests the classic. The column is seemingly endless, winding in and around the hills and wadis of the distance like a snake.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, BRADLEY'S OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: watching through his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Battalion strength...at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The German Infantry begins a series of geometric move- ments, deploying into combat formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We barely hear German commands shouted as the companies break rhythmically into smaller groups ami then, in turn, smaller yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAMOUFLAGE NETS
dialogues.text: The American gun positions, with double foxholes dug near the guns. The hot sun throws patterns through the camouflage netting. Small groups of infantry waiting near the gun crews.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PATTON'S OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: Patton and Jenson watch silently.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON
dialogues.text: They haven't spotted our positions yet.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: They'll get an education in about twenty seconds... Wait'll they get a dose of that time-fire. Camera moves in close on Patton. Binoculars to his eyes, he is tense, barely able to control his inner excitement.  104 105 106 107 108 109 ll. i212

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The infantry is through the bottleneck, proceeding withou knowing the positions of the Americans. They move closer, closer -- and suddenly the American artillery opens up with devastating air bursts, stunning the infantry and temporarily sending them into disorder. They are quickly reorganized and now the offensive is reasserted.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW FROM PATTON'S OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: The insect infantry crawls forward to serious casualties.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What a helluva way to waste fine infantry. ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The German troops move into the blazing deatn-dealing line of U.S. fire. Suddenly we notice sixty Nazi tanks coming through the El Guettar pass, charging across the plains after the infantry. They seem like beetles run- hing back and forth on the plain, scurrying blindly along stopping and almost waving their antennae, running again, like small beads in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: LONG SHOT
dialogues.text: The artillery shells burst in the air like ugly flowers. It is truly a color spectacle, the gold and blue of the desert terrain and the sudden black blossoming of the air bursts. ;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as four Heinkel fighter-bombers roar down from out of the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THE HEINKELS
dialogues.text: swooping down on the contest below, bombing a column of American tanks moving under cover of a wadi. Two tanks are hit and burst into yellow flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The blast has practically split the lead Sherman apart. The crewmen leap out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PATTON'S COMMAND POST
dialogues.text: We can see the flaming smoke rising from the tanks. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {to Jenson, fiercely) Dick -- go tell General Bradley to hit ‘em hard on that right flank. Here's where we hold 'em by the nose and kick ‘em in the ass. Jenson leaves.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY'S OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: Jenson clambers up the rocky hillside to Bradley's positi He finds Bradley and Hansen watching the battle. Yelling above the din, Jenson is relaying Patton's instructions to Bradley, when the sound of approaching aircraft is heard. Jenson and a Sergeant take cover in a small rocky fold in the ground. Bradley and Hansen dive into ditches.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN HEINKELS
dialogues.text: approaching. MED, SHOT - BRADLEY'S OBSERVATION POsT with Bradley's ditch in f.g. Bradley's long legs can be seen sticking up out of the shallow ditch -- also his Springfield rifle,

dialogues.speaker: RANSEN
dialogues.text: (yelling over noise of approaching planes) Get your legs down, General!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (he tries, grins) 'Fraid they're too long, Chet. The planes roar over, their bombs exploding as they hit. One enormous explosion hits between Bradley's ditch and the spot where Jenson and the Sergeant have taken cover. Debris fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: As the debris clears, he picks up his precious Springfiel finds a jagged hole in the stock. He works the bolt, ejecting a shell, then shoves the bolt home, satisfied the piece works. He looks o.s., is sobered by what he sees.  66 117 118- 125 126 127 128 129 130 131 132 133 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley rises, moves over to where the Sergeant is bendin over the lifeless body of Jenson. Recognizing that Jenson is dead, Bradley is deeply affected.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (to Sergeant ) Put him on my jeep. our

dialogues.speaker: THE BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: As the German tanks advance toward camera, there suddenly appears behind them, emerging from a wadi on the German left flank, a group of American tanks. They cut in sharply and open fire on the Germans from the rear.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: The tank commander has spotted the Americans, and the tank lumbers slowly around to meet the new threat.

dialogues.speaker: INT, GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: An explosion rocks the tank. The tank commander yelis something indistinguishable to his driver, who franticall tries to wheel the vehicle around.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN TANK COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Looking through his periscope, his eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: German tanks are wheeling to meet the threat to their rear as American armor pours out of the wadi, firing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TURRET OF GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: There is an explosion as the turret takes a hit, the hatc springing open and belching smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: Now the battle in full perspective. The American tanks have caught the Germans by surprise and cut across their rear, while the anti-tank positions which have been threatened continue to fire. Every so often there is a direct hit and a German tank goes up in smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tank does a screeching pinwheel movement, turning about and firing at the flank of a German tank,  66 134 136 137 138 139 140 wi 142 143 38

dialogues.speaker: SIDE OF GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: The shell hits and the tread springs apart with a screech ing sound.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: The hatch opens and the Germans, face-blackened from the flames, leap out -- one of them actually on fire.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN INFANTRY
dialogues.text: The line of skirmishers has taken cover as a German tank fires at them with its machine guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealing German Infantry advancing on the Americans, taking cover behind the tanks. They fire at the American Infantrymen and the Americans fire back.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: It heads for the line of American Infantry.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN BAZOOKAMAN
dialogues.text: He lines up his sights and fires the weapon. As the bazooka round hits, the tank explodes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He puts the binoculars to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE
dialogues.text: that many of the German tanks are aflame. Less than thirt are turning to escape.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW DOLLY IN ON PATTON
dialogues.text: looking through binoculars,

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (the highest possible level of jubilation) Rommel, you stupid bastard, I read your book!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S OBSERVATION POST
dialogues.text: Patton is in b.g. faced away from camera, still trium- Phantly scanning the battlefield. Into f.g. comes Bradley's jeep, with the General in the front seat and Jenson's body laid across the rear seat. Preoccupied, Patton is paying no attention as Bradley gets out of the jeep, walks slowly over toward Patton.  a Usd © Ws 1h6 147

dialogues.speaker: LATE DAY
dialogues.text: On a rise, in outline against the reddening sky, is a two-wheel ammunition caisson. Atop the caisson is a stretcher on which is a man's body in a white GI mattress cover, Camera moves in.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.8.) Captain Richard N. Jenson was a fine boy - leyal, unselfish and efficient. I am terribly sorry. A hend uncovers the face of Jenson and camera reveals Patton as he touches the face, then kisses it and finally kmeels beside the caisson. Camera lifts away to reveal Meeks-and Patton's Driver bringing up a pair of black- blenketed horses which they hitch to the yoke of the caisson.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) There are no coffins here, since there is no wood...We will have a trumpeter and honor guard, but we will not fire the volleys, as it would make people think an air raid was on.

dialogues.speaker: JENSON'S FACE
dialogues.text: as Patton's hands enclose it within the mattress cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enclosed a lock of Dick's hair in a letter to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small ceremonial cortege, including Carver and Stiller, comes to attention as Patton rises.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.3s.) He was a fine man and a fine officer and he had no vices. I shall mias him a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caisson moves off with Meeks and Patton's Driver leading the horses, Stiller behind the caisson and Patton abreast of it. Cont.  66 147 Cont. 148- 153 4o
I can't see the reason such fine young men get killed. There are so many battles yet to fight. Camera widens to see the small procession make its way across the vast desert floor.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE NEWSREEL
dialogues.text: This film, with newsreel quality, is seen in World War II aspect ratio, with rousing stock music.

dialogues.speaker: LINK UP IN TUNISIA
dialogues.text: (NOTE: All newsreel titles ‘throughout the film will bear the Fox Movietone News logo.) Ae

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Exhausted groups of British troops in faded summer combat dress have come face to face with equaily battle-worn American troops in their heavyweight combat 0.D.s. In contrast to the high-key narration, we see that the cameramen, trying not to be included, are frantically signaling the diffident men to greet each other in some sort of enthusiastic demonstration. Very obviously taking directions, the soldiers per- ~functorily greet each other, exchange cigarettes and shake hands -- all for the folks back home. Overhead our planes can be seen.

eee but victorious, American GIs and Tommies of the British Eighth Army meet in a joyful allied victory celebration at Wadi Akarit in North Africa. For the first time in this war, Broadway and Piccadilly join hands!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON IN TANK
dialogues.text: Patton, dressed to the teeth, is in the open turret of a tank, scanning the far horizon with as fierce and hammy an expression as he can muster for the newsreels -- which was pretty fierce and hammy. Cont.  66 aL 148- Cont. 153 154

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant General George S. Patton, Jr., colorful and hard-driving commander of the American Second Corps, gives U.S. troops a ‘great victory in North Africa when he defeats the seasoned panzers of German Field Marshal Rommel at El Guettar.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY IN JEEP
dialogues.text: Montgomery, a totally different personality but just as image-conscious in his own way, is dressed in beret, turtle-neck sweater and corduroy pants. As his jeep drives alongside a column of British troops, he favors them with a wave and a "one of the boys" smile -- even reaches out to shake a few hands as he passes. The men cheer him wildly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (0.s.) Meanwhile, General Montgomery, hero of El Alamein, continues to lead his veteran and victorious British Eighth Army in a relentless drive against Rommel's vaunted Africa Corps. (NOTE: END OF NEWSREEL)

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Bradley is seated on an ammo box in front of his tent, with a towel draped around his neck, as a GI gives him a haircut. Suddenly the sound of an approaching aircraft cuts the stillness. Bradley looks up, frowning, as it roars by close overhead.

dialogues.speaker: PIPER CUB
dialogues.text: Patton grins and waves to Bradley from the small spotter plane, which is coming in for a ianding.

dialogues.speaker: CUB STRIP
dialogues.text: This is no more than a field cleared of brush and adjoins Bradley's headquarters. Bradley pulis the towei off his neck as he moves over to meet the little plane that has landed and is taxiing toward him,  66 155 4e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane stops and Patton steps out. There's a bounce to his step and a glint in his eye as he comes over to Bradley.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Brad -- if you've got any whisky, you can buy us both a drink!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head apologetically) George, I don't believe I have a thing --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Well, I've got something for you. (takes three-star pin from his pocket hands it to Bradley} Three stars!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (looking at them fondly) I knew this was in the works -- but I didn't know it had Senate approval.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: That's nothing but a formality. Put 'em on!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (putting them in his pocket) I'd just as soon wait --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You're a corps commander, Brad! Ike's giving you command of Second Corps.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Well, I'1l be doggoned -- (suddeniy) What about’ you?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I'm going to Seventh Army at Mostaganem tc take over planning for the Sicily operation.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Congratulations, George. Cont.  155 Cont. 43

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I'd like to see you come along and take Second Corps into Sicily... If you want to, I'll fix it with Ike.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (pleased by the prospect of a corps command) Nothing I'd like better.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You'll have to clean up the situation here in North Africa first.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: That's okay with me -- (he breaks into a sudden, eager grin) Tell you what I do have, George --~ couple of bottles of warm beer.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (gruffly) Well, why the hell didn't you say so? A man could die of thirst around here! Grinning, Bradley leads the way toward his tent.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Jodi's staff, including Steiger, are gathered around a table, and Jodl is concluding the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: It is obvious that North Africa will soon be lost. We must now anticipate the enemy's next move and I will expect a staff report in the next twenty-four hours. {nodding dismissal) That will be all. The Officers rise, go about their business. Jodl passes by Steiger, who alone has remained seated. Beside him is a stack of books and clippings.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: You, Steiger -- you haven't said @ word.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: No one asked me to, sir. Cont,  66 156 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I'm asking you now. You think Patton will attack Sardinia?

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Patton, sir, is a military historian. He knows that Sicily, not Sardinia, has always been the key to Italy. If Patton has anything to say about it, he will probably attack Sicily at Syracuse -- (with a faint, fond smile) -- as the Athenians did.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (impatient and annoyed Steiger --! This is the Twentieth Century!

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: But you must understand, General -- Patton is a Sixteenth Century man. He digs a volume out of his pile of books, flips to a marked page.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Just listen to this: (reading) 'On a quiet street in New York, in nineteen twenty-two, Patton was on his way to a dinner, wearing white tie and tails, when he came upon three men pushing a young girl into the back of a truck. He leaped out of his car, produced a revolver, and forced the men at gunpoint to release the woman.' (as though this were the punch line of a marvelous joke) It turned out the woman was the fiancee of one of the men, and he wes merely helping her into the truck! Cont.  oO

dialogues.speaker: 4S
dialogues.text: 156 Cont.1 STEIGER (Cont.) (relishing the story) What could be more revealing?

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about!

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: (it's all so clear) Don Quixote encounters six merchants of Toledo on the road and saves Dulcinea's virtue!

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Who the devil is Dulcinea?

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Don't you see, sir? Patton is a romantic warrior, lost in contemporary times...The secret of Patton is the past. He'll urge an attack on Sicily because that's what the Athenians did!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: This elaborate house looks out over the bay at Mostaganen

dialogues.speaker: MGSTAGANEM, ALGERIA
dialogues.text: Camera moves in on a loggia where Patton is talking to GENERAL CARVER.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: General Bradley's done a tremendous job with Second Corps. He's moved into Bizerte and taken over forty- one thousand prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (approvingly) Good...Damn good!

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: (smiling) You're not surprised, are you, sir? After all, you trained that outfit. Fatton nods, moves on. inside, followed by Carver. 66  66 159 46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army and Navy officers and their aides speed back and forth and there is a mumble of conversation. LIEUTENANT GOLONEL CHARLES R. CODMAN, a dapper debonair and unflappable man in his mid-forties, starts forward as Patton enters, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel (now full Colonel) Davenport moves across the room toward Patton, pre-empting the General's attention.

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, General -- Patton is distracted by his cigar, which has gone dead. He puffs frantically, but it is out. Almost instantly Codman appears in scene, whips out a Zippo and lights the General's cigar. Patton accepts the light without noticing Codman. His job with the Zippo done, Codman disappears from the scene. Davenport resumes, glancing at paper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: Sir, this is interesting. We've discovered that Rommel wasn't present at El Guettar.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (taking this as a personal affront ) Who says 30?

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: G-2, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (grabs the report; then fiercely They trying to tell me that when we took on Tenth Panzer, Rommel was in Berlin with an earache?

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: {always the facts) Severe nasal diphtheria, sir... G-2 also reports that Hitler probably retained Rommel in Berlin because things were going badly for the Africa Corps and he wanted his favorite general to save face. Cont.  66 7 159 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Well, I'm my favorite general and won't be told that some second- stringer was in command against me. Then I lose face! He puffs frantically but the cigar has gone dead again. As if by magic, Codman appears, applies the lighted Zippo Patton gets the cigar going, notices Codman for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (growling) Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: General, this is Lieutenant Colonel Codman, your new aide.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. (remembering) I pulled your name off the list because I know your family. CcODMAN I'm glad you did, sir. PaTTON Codman, that Kraut Rommel is the best they have -- and I kicked hell out of him. Now my own G-2 section is trying to tell me he wasn't even there!

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (polite, diplomatic, soothingly quiet) But, General, he undoubtedly planned the German battle. Patton glares at him, frowning, unsure of Codman's point. cODMAN If you defeat Rommel's plan, you've defeated Rommel. Isn't that true, sir? Somewhat mollified, Patton takes a long pull on the cigar as he studies his new aide, finds more here than meets th eye. Obviously a man of taste and discretion.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Codman, I want you to have a drink with me tonight. Cont.  48 159 Cant.1

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I nave a plan for the invasion of Sicily and I want to make sure I get it approved. You can help me. Codmean nods.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I want to give a dinner for General Alaxander. Want to get to him before Montgomery does... This'll be a formal affair, Codman -- but purely social. Tarily) By that I mean purely political.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I want the finest food and the best wines available. {eyeing Codman appraisingly) sverything comme il faut.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (nodding, unruffled) Entendu, mon General.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (pleased with Codman's French) Quelque chose vraiment special.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Ca va sans dire...Qui aimeriez- vous inviter?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Le Marechal Alexander et son Chef ad'Etat-Major. Peut-etre Tedder. Fas trop de monde et plutot intime, d' accord?

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: D'iaccord, mon General -- Caught up in his planning, Patton has wandered off with Codman, leaving Carver and Davenport staring after them, amazed by the boss' command of French. 66  66 160 161 4g

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Codman stands, immaculately dressed, appraising the party he has arranged. Through the alcove, past an impressive line of fins paintings, a GI can be seen at a piano, playing a Beethoven sonata. Camere moves through the alcove into a palatial dining room, where a magnificent table is laid in the classic manner. There is a mumble of dinner conversation as the camera moves along one side of the table, revealing the elegantl uniformed allied officers. Camera holds for a moment on AIR CHIEF MARSHAL SIR ARTHUR TEDDER.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF, MEDITERRANEAN AIR COMMAND
dialogues.text: Camera continues on past Carver. At the end of the table, seated on Patton's right, is GENERAL SIR HAROLD R.L.G. ALEXANDER.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY COMMANDER, ALLIED FORCE
dialogues.text: Working on Alexander, Patton, of course, leads the conversation. PaTTON You remember, General, what Alcibiades ‘said in four fifteen B.C. during the Peloponnesian War: ‘If Syracuse falls, all Sicily falls -- then Italy!' He lmew that Syracuse was the jugular of the island -~- and Alcibiades always went for the throat. Alexander, impressed, glances approvingly at Tedder.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I propose to take Sicily the same way!

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Davenport approaches Codman, who is keeping a keen supervisory eye on the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: i think the old man has them in his pocket.  66 162 163 164 50

dialogues.speaker: INT, DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Patton has pulled a set of drapes, revealing a wall map ef Sicily. He is at the map illustrating his points, which are of course directed to Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: According to my plan, General, Montgomery will land here. (he points to Syracuse ) ‘I will hit the beach here and seize the port of Palermo. Monty can pin down the Germans in the south, while I drive east, take the city of Messina, and cut off the escape route of the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (impressed) Looks like an interesting plan, George.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (expansively, to the group) Gentlemen ~~ here's to the conquest of Sicily! They ali raise their glasses and sip their wine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (admiringly} You know, George, you would have made a great marshal for Napoleon if you had lived in the Eighteenth Century.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with a quiet, confident smile) But I did, Sir Harold -- I did! Alexander laughs, catering good-humorediy to his host. Patton smiles, because he is riding the crest of a diplomatic triumph, but he is actually quite serious.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: MONTGOMERY drives up in a staff car, gets out and hurries into the building.  66 165 166 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Montgomery moves down the corridor, SUPERIMPOSE:

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDING GENERAL, BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY
dialogues.text: Montgomery moves to the doorway of an office, the open door of which is marked MAJOR GENERAL WALTER BEDELL SMITH He speaks to someone inside.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Pardon me -- General Smith in?
I believe he's in the lavatory, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Thank you. He turns and moves on down the corridor. iNT, LAVATORY - DAY GENERAL SMITH is washing his hands at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF OF STAFF TO GENERAL EISENHOWER
dialogues.text: Montgomery enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- there you are...Beetle, I've been giving a good bit of thought to the Sicily operation.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I assume we're alone -- Montgomery quickly scans the bottom of the stalls, making sure no alien feet are present. ‘SMITH You know Georgie Patton's already discussed his plan with Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I realize that. I have an idea his play may lead to an absolute disaster. He leans forward, exhales his breath over the mirror, creating a fog area. He draws on this with his finger. Cont.  66 52 166 Cont. 167 168 169

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Beetle, look: This is Sicily. According to Patton's plan, I would attack Syracuse - here - and he would attack Palermo -- up here. Obviously our forces would be divided -- and just as obviously we could be chopped up piecemeal. (with some asperity) Wnat I propose -- and what I shall insist on, by the way -- is this: I land at Syracuse as planned. But the Americans land here at Gela. I drive north to Messina, with the Americans protecting my flank... After all, Messina is the key. It's the reason for invading Sicily!

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'll tell Ike about this and I'm sure he'll give it serious consideration. They go out together.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Amusing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
