dialogues.text: The final plans for the invasion of Sicily having been put forward in an Algerian lavatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cavernous darkness there is the ear-splitting roar of tank engines. Then the huge doors in the bow of the vessel open, admitting sudden bright sunlight. <A tank with snorkel equipment moves out of f.g., waddles ponder- ously out onto the ramp.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Standing in the turret of the tank is Patton, impatient and enraged when the tank hesitates, poised on the edge of the ramp. He cails down into the tank.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Come on -- get the lead out!  66 170 171 172 173 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRIVER and the ASSISTANT DRIVER can be seen at the controls, with Patton's legs in evidence from the turret. The engine noise is loud in the confined space, and the men have to yell.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT DRIVER
dialogues.text: (to Driver, nervously) No! Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT DRIVER
dialogues.text: I don't want to get drowned in this damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s. roaring, from above) Do I have’ to come down there myself?!

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT DRIVER
dialogues.text: (to Driver, gesturing him forward) : Go ahead. I'd rather drown.

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: The huge vehicle waddles forward off the ramp, dropping into the surf that covers its tracks. However, it survive and moves up the beach.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S STAFF
dialogues.text: Carver, Davenport, Bell, Codman and several other officer are watching and grinning as "the old man" demonstretes the new equipment successfully. A staff car drives up and the staff salutes snappily as General Alexander steps out

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: The huge vehicle has stopped at the water line, and Patto jumps down out of the turret as Codman comes into scene.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (exuberantly) It works, Codman, it works! With that snorkel equipment, we can land any place!

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: General Alexander is here, sir -- Patton turns, moves off toward staff car.  66 174 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton comes into scene and salutes as Alexander gets out of the car. Alexander returns the salute, then the two men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (full of enthusiasm) Sir Harold, congratulations on a great British invention. If it weren't so damn secret I'd like to call in the photographers.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: George, I have bad news for you about your Sicily plan. I'm afraid Ike has turned it down. Patton is both amazed and annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: He feels that since the Italians will be defending their native soil for the first time, and since German resistance is stiffening, our forces shouldn't be divided.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Where do I land then?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: in the Gulf of Gele.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What for? There's nothing there but a beach.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes, but it puts you in good position to support Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (evenly) And where does Montgomery land?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: He'll land in Syracuse and drive north to Catania -- possibly even Messina. You'll be alongside, protecting his left.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (bitterly) You mean we get the burden again, while good old Monty gets the glory. Cont.  55 174 Cont. 175

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ike had to consider all points of view. He made his decision not as an American but as an ally. (after a moment) If it were the other way ‘round, I assure you Monty would protest.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No, dammit, I've been in the Army thirty years, and when I get an order, I say ‘Yes, sir', and do my damndest to carry it out. (unable to contain his fury, he growls) But this is what you get when your commander-in-chief stops being an American and becomes an ally.

dialogues.speaker: INT, REICHSCHANCELLERY
dialogues.text: On a screen in the darkened room we see projected in black and white (and without sound) uncut U.S. Signal Corps footage of Patton landing on the beach at Gela. Harkins and other staff officers are with him. In some of the shots Signal Corps cameramen appear with their hand-held Eyemos. Patton steps off a landing craft and wades ashore with his fiercest expression, pistols on his hips, shiny helmet gleaming, surrounded by his staff. Since this is uncut footage, we see the Signal Corps slate -- PATTON - SICILY LANDING - ROLL 3. There follows other angles of the same action, revealing that this is staged for the cameras with Patton's willing - if not eager - cooperation. We even see him put on his fierce warlike scowl the moment the cameras roll. During the above, the following is heard from o.s.:

dialogues.speaker: JODL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (9.s8.) Here is the gangster Patton arriving on the beach at Gela with his Seventh Army.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) This film was captured after the ianding. Camera pulls back and we recognize the map room in which are seated several Wehrmacht officers in addition to Jodl and Steiger. The room, of course, is in color, the film Cont.  56 175 Cont. on the screen being the only thing in black and white. The Army footage continues, showing action shots of troop going ashore and other aspects of the amphibious landing. The German officers continue their conversation as they watch shots of Patton on the beach yelling orders at individual soldiers, cursing them as he urges them inland

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: I didn't realize he was so tall.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Over six feet.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: He is constantly giving personal commands.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Obviously they now have two prima donnas in Sicily -- Montgomery and Patton, On the screen there appears a shot of Bradley landing with his troops on another beach. Wearing ordinary GI uniform except for the stars on his helmet, he steps into the surf with a few of his staff, carrying a carbine and almost indistinguishable from the soldiers landing with him. The whole tone is as unpretentious and businesslike as Petton was flamboyant.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: There's another three-star general. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: This is General Bradley. He commands the American Second Corps.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: He looks like a common soldier.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: He is extremely capable and completely unpretentious. Most unusual for a general. {he turns to find Jodl glaring at him; quickly) I beg your pardon, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley's jeep moves down road toward Patton's command post in b.g.  57 177 aes PATTON'S COMMAND POST - A FARMHOUSE IN SOUTHERN

dialogues.speaker: ICILY
dialogues.text: Patton, Bell and Codman are in the elaborate but portable map room. Bell is at a map of Sicily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I've made myself clear, sir. It's true that Montgomery has met the toughest resistance of the campaign here at Catania. However --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (secretly enjoying himself) It's perfectly clear. Monty's as stuck as a bug on flypaper.

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: ‘(indicating paper in bis hand) . But this order from General Alexander... he's directing you to give up the Vizzini-Caltagirone Road and turn it over to Montgomery!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (shrugging) So Bradley will have to fight his way up the center over tough mountain roads -- that's all. a BELL (eyeing Patton uncertainly) Yes, sir --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (nudging Bell, he taps the map at Messina) : Here's where the ball game is, Bell -- up here at Messina. If they'd used my plan, I'd have been there by this time and cut off the escape of every damn Kraut and Italian on this island... But I'll tell you what I'm going to do now. I'm going to Palermo first, then I'm going to beat that Limey into Messina! Bradley enters,.his face grim, something obviously on his mind. Cont. 66  66 177 Cont. 58

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George -- what's this about taking the Vizzini Road away from Second Corps?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: General Alexander's orders. He says the road goes to Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: That road was assigned to me. How am I going to move north without it? You know the terrain up there.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his heart bleeding) I know, Brad, but Monty's run into tough opposition -- very tough. Bradley glances at the map, then eyes Patton with growing suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George -- you wouldn't be taking advantage of this situation, would you?

dialogues.speaker: . PATTON
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Without that road, all of your army but my Second Corps is out of a job. Free to go on to Palermo, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Who said anything about Palermo?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: I can read a map. (indicating probing salients on map) Does Alexander know you've pushed out this far?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (waving this aside) Hell, that's nothing but a reconnaissance in force.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (firmly accusing) George, are you telling me I've got to slug it out over those mountains with heavy resistance just so you can make a bigger splash than Monty? Cont.  59 177 Cont.1 ‘@) PATTON (full of helpless innocence) Brad, I just carry out my orders, like the simple old soldier I am. Carver enters with a teletype dispatch in his hand. He nods respectfully to Bradley.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: General Bradley -- (to Patton) Sir, General Alexander's gotten wind of your westerly movement. He says here: 'Stop immediately. Go no farther than Agrigento. Repeat, stop immediately.'

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (eyeing Carver for a moment) That's what you think it says. But I think it was garbled in transmission. Ask them to re- transmit the message -- and take your time about it. @ (with a wink at Bradley) That'll take half a day at least.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He goes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Where were we, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (slowly, accusingly, his eyes fixed on Patton) We were talking about e simple ald soldier... 178 EXT. ROAD TO PALERMO - LONG SHOT - DaY Columns of Patton's tanks and self-propelled artillery sp along the primitive Sicilian road. There is no resistance ag the tanks barrel along with hatches open and infantry- men on top. 66  66 179 180 181 182 183 60

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Patton's armored command car, along with the rest of his entourage, races past a column of two-and-a-half-ton trucks, its siren blasting. A line of Italian prisoners is being herded to the rear.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND CODMAN
dialogues.text: Standing up in the command vehicle, Patton views the scen of speeding, clanking, irresistible power with undisguise exultation.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (rapturously ) Look, Cod. Could anything be more magnificent?!... I must tell the truth -- I love it. Goddammit, I do love it! Codman glances at him, not quite sure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, HILLY COUNTRY IN SICILY
dialogues.text: Bradley's jeep, in which are Bradley, his driver, Hansen and Bradley's Second Aide, drives along a road by a farm- house held by an American infantry platoon, From a hillside nearby, German artillery is pounding the area.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: As the jeep approaches the farmhouse, the shelling grows more intense. A shell hits too close for comfort and, at a signal from Bradley, all four men bail out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley and his party take cover. As a shell hits nearby, a GI from the infantry platoon also dives for cover behin the wall. There is another tremendous explosion and debris rains down on the men huddled behind the wall. The GI pulls himseif up, unable to see from his position the insignia worn by the others.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Wonder what silly sonuvabitch is in charge of this operation!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (with a wry, private grin) I don't know, but they ought to hang him.  66 184 185 186 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A British Colonel stands before the desk of Montgomery, who refers sternly to a piece of paper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I want this communique entirely rewritten. British armies are never "bogged down by enemy resistance’. We ‘momentarily slow our advance to prepare for new and stunning blows against the enemy'. (scathingly) If you're going to write, Welkin, for God's sake use a little imagination!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton's cavalcade storms up to the headquarters and pull to a halt. Out in front, as Patton steps down from his command car, is a group of four or five clergymen, in clerical collars, being escorted by the Seventh Army CHAPLAIN. Patton greets him in high good humor.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: ‘Afternoon, Chaplain --

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: General, these gentlemen are here from the States looking over our program for the spiritual welfare of the men.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Good. Stick with us and we'll take you into Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: CLERGYMAN
dialogues.text: (indicating Chaplain) Colonel Davis showed us your quarters, General Patton, and I was interested to see a Bible beside your bed. Do you actually find time to read 1%?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Ga dead earnest) I sure do... Every goddamn day.

dialogues.speaker: INT, REICHSCHANCELLERY MAP ROOM
dialogues.text: Steiger approaches Jodl, who is studying a wall map of the Russian front.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Sir -- the Americans have taken Palermo!

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Damn!  ©

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery sits at a table, dressed in his roguish, casua Manner, as an AIDE enters.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: General -- Patton's taken Palermo!

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (explosively) Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves up the inclined road, whizzing past crowds o Sicilians chanting in a definite rhythm: "Viva, viva, viv viva.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATTON ENTOURAGE
dialogues.text: Two command cars and two jeeps. With Patton are Codman an Davenport.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (enjoying himself enormously) Palermo is the most conquered city in the world. The Phoenicians, the Carthaginians, the Romans, the Byzantines. Then came the Arabs, the Speniards, the Neapolitans. And now me.

dialogues.speaker: CROWDED STREET
dialogues.text: Patton's vehicles press through the cheering crowd as peo offer lemons and watermelons to the victorious Americans. A motorcycle courier makes his way through the crowd, draws up alongside the command car. He holds out a messag which Codman reaches over and takes from his hand. TwO SHOT - PATTON AND CODMAN Codman has glanced at the message.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (with a grin) This is from General Alexander, sir, reminding you that you are not to take Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Send him a message, Codman. Ask him if hs wants me to give it back.  66 192 193 ao Ae MeD. LONG SHOT The Patton convoy comes to a halt in front of a cathedral at the entrance to which stands a Cardinal in all his fin Leaving the car, Patton strides over and kisses the Cardi ring, a gesture which is theatrically perfect and brings a ringing cheer from the people lining the sidewalk. EXT. PATTON'S PALAZZO IN PALERMO ~ FULL VIEW - DaY At each of the four corners of the palace a tank, fully manned, stands guard. Patton is conducting a press conference on the lawn. He stands like a conquering king, wearing a custom-tailored whipcord jacket. CORRESPONDENTS sit about the lawn on folding chairs.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {ebullientiy) For a change, let me ask you a question. You've just come from Washington. What's the reaction to our boys taking Palermo?

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Well, sir -- the general impression is that your Seventh Army berreled through token resistance, while Montgomery faced the brunt of the fighting.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his smile hits the ground like a sack of lemons) By God, don't they know we took on the Eerman Goering Division, the toughest outfit in the German army?

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: The people back home are interested in you, General. They're curious about your peari-handled revolvers.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (outraged) They're ivory! Wobody but a pimp for a cheap New Orleans whorehouse would carry a pearl-handled pistol!

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT 33
dialogues.text: What about your languege, Generel? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: WY
dialogues.text: 193 Cont. 6h

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: When I want something to stick, I give it to them loud and dirty so they'll remember it.

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT 72
dialogues.text: How do the men react to that?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: God dammnit, I don't want these men to love me -- I want them to fight Tor me! (eyes flashing, jaw set)

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: Ernie Pyle says you've got a secret weapon here in Sicily -- General Bradley. ‘The GI General' -- that's what Ernie calls him.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (gruffly) Omer Bradley's no secret. He's a damn fine commander.

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT 73
dialogues.text: Whet's your feeling about Montgomery?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He's the best generel the Limeys have. But he's more concerned about not losing a battle than he is about winning one.

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (baiting him) You think he's not aggressive enough -- is that correct? Patton notices the men have been scribbling furiously, starts to pull back. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a, 193 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute, boys -- I've been getting into enough trouble lately. Yesterday the Inspector General's office told me my Italian prisoners didn't have enough latrines. They never knew what a goddamn latrine was until I showed them! (this gets a laugh) So if anything I've said sounded critical of my distinguished British colleague -- I hope you'll just forget it. (again unable to resist, he smiles) I will tell you this, off the record. I'm going to beat the sonuvabitch into Messina!

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: The headline reads: PATTON VOWS TO TAKE MESSINA,

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE STALLED BRITISH ALLIES
dialogues.text: Camera pulls back to reveal the newspaper is in Montgomery's hand. Monty is building up a head of steam as he reads. MAJOR GENERAL DE GUINGAND enters with a report in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY'S CHIEF OF STAFF
dialogues.text: Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a, 194 Cont. 65

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (outraged) Freddy, do you realize what this madman Patton is seying? He's going to save our skins by taking Messina}

dialogues.speaker: DE GUINGAND
dialogues.text: You might find this report interesting, sir. :

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (his smoldering jealousy building) Here I am in these bloody marshes, fighting malaria as well as Germans,,. while he's taking Palermo without opposition and getting all the glory. (having glanced at report, elatedly) Well! Now he's up against three good Jerry divisions and he's stuck for a change... He's not going to get Messina. That's reserved for the British Eighth Army and me!

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: They are walking through an olive grove toward the head- quarters, Both men appear concerned, preoccupied, ARTILLERY FIRE can be heard in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: It's very simple, Lucian. Terry Allen's bogged down east of Troina. Youtre bogged down on the coast road. We need an end run here to break things loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton has appeared at the doorway of the farmhouse. Cont.  66 197 Cont. 66

dialogues.speaker: FATTON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, do you realize where we are? We're'in an olive grove where Hannibal may have wandered. (warmly) Lucian! How's my little fighting sonuvabitch? (motioning them inside) Come on in. Brad and I have a job for you. We tried the same thing last week and picked up twelve miles. Everybody from old man Churchill on down was waving our flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton crosses to map, jabs with his cigar, describing en arc around the Germen defenses on coast road.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Lucian -- we want you to senda reinforced battalion by sea to make @ landing up hsre behind the Kraut lines. Last week we brought in sixteen hundred prisoners that way.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: General Bradley says you want me to tie this in with a land-based attack.

dialogues.speaker: PATION
dialogues.text: That's right... I want a coordinated assault the morning of the eleventh.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: I don't think we can make the linkup by the eleventh.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Hell, it's only fifteen or twenty miles!

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: General, my boys have been fighting and dying for yards.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Maybe you better Kick a few butts if you have to. (a warm personal appeal) Lucian -+ I recommended you for your DSM end your last promotion. JI know what you can do if you put your mind to it. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- I can't do the impossible!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Dammnit, Lucian, you're too old an athlete to think you can postpone a match that's been scheduled.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: You're an old athlete yourself, sir. You know that matches sometimes are postponed.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George -- if Lucian's right and we can't back it up by land, our end run could ‘be a disaster. Those men might get caught up there on the beach and cut to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (thoroughly annoyed) What's the matter with you two?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: All we're talking about is not rushing in before we're ready... Give him an extra day.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: Just one more day --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (angrily) I will like heli! The landing is on. We're going to Messina and we're going to get there before Monty does.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: What's so important about that? Infuriated by this challenge to his own indefensible position, Patton seethes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Truscott, if your conscience won't let you conduct this operation, I will relieve you and let someone else do it. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: WF
dialogues.text: os oO. 68 198 Cont.2

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: General, it's your privilege to relieve me anytime you want to. There is a long moment, during which Patton gets his ange under control. He speaks with absolute authority.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this match will not be postponed. (to Truscott) You got any questions?

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: No, sir. Patton breaks the tension by setting out three glasses from a tray on his desk and reaching for the decanter.

dialogues.speaker: PATTOW
dialogues.text: (as he pours three drinks) Llucian -- you're a good man, but you're too damn conservative... You know what Frederick the Great said? Always audacity! 'Ltaudace, l'audace, toujovrs l'audace!! (shoving *® glass toward Truscott) Come on -- let's have a drink. Unwilling to bend the knee, Truscott speaks with quiet dignity.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir -- I'm not going to be drinking the next couple of days. He salutes, turns and goes out. Patton glances over to find Bradley's eyes staring at him evenly.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Ceorge, if anything happens to those men, I want to be with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're not going -~- so forget it. (belligerently resentful) What are you trying to tell me -- that Truscott's right? Cont.  © 66 69 198 Cont.2 199 200 201- 20h, 205 206

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (his sense of outrage taking over) You're gambling with the lives of those boys just so you can beat Montgomery into Messina. If you pull it off, you're a hero. But if you don't, what about them? Think about the ordinary combat soldier, He doesn't share your dreams of glory. He's stuck here -- living out every day with death tugging at his elbow. {his bitter anger growing) There's one big difference betwean you and me, George. I do this job because I'm trained to do it. You do it because you love it! Bradley turns and walks out, leaving Patton staring afte> hin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combat-equipped infantrymen are huddled in the dark landing craft, torn as always between hope and fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A. The landing craft let down their ramps with a huge splash. B. They disgorge their cargo of assault troops. C. The infantrymen make e silent and unopposed dash across the sand to an embankment beside the coast road.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: From far down the road the sound of an approaching ENGIN: is heard. In a momens we can see a motorcycle with side- car, then we recognize the rider as a Cerman soldier.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKING
dialogues.text: In the dark, the word is passed in a whisper from one rifleman to the next, eamera following as each man receives and passes on the message: Cont,  70 206 Cont. 207 208 209 210- 211 212- 214 215 66

dialogues.speaker: RIFLEMAN
dialogues.text: Hold your fire. This is repeated in turn by two or three succeeding riflemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silence is shattered by the sharp clatter of the moto eycle's engine. Shooting down the line of riflemen, we can see their heads turn as the word to hold fire is passed toward camera. But a soldier in f.g. who has not yet got the word, sees the approaching German cyclist. He raises his rifle and fires.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: as the German cyclist is hit. He screams and his motor- eycle slews wildly off the road, depositing his twisted body in a ditch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting over the riflemen taking cover behind it. There is a sudden, startling flash of light as a parachute flar illuminates the area. Then, from the wooded rise across the road, all hell breaks loose. Machine guns, mortars and small arms fire suddenly comes pouring onto the beach

dialogues.speaker: SERI
dialogues.text: German machine guns and mortars firing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American Infantrymen take what cover they can egainst the enbankment, but the mortar shells lob in as they find the range. A. Infantryman getting hit. B. Landing craft shoving off beach under heavy mortar fir C, Riflemen who have scrambled to the top of the enbank- ment to fire are cut down by machine gun bursts. INT, PATTON'S HEADQUARTERS aT FORWARD COMMAND POST -

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Carver is on a field phone and Patton is pacing the floor his face a storm cloud of frustration. Cont.  C) 215 Cont. 216 217 218 219 66 72

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: (holding the phone) Those men on the beach are really catching hell, General. Truscott's men are doing their best, but we have no replacements for him and he cantt break through to the coast.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with sudden grim decision) I'm going up there myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of tanks is halted beside the river. The COLONEL in command, his helmet off, is fuming over a map with a couple of staff officers.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s., roaring as from a distance) Colonel -- ! The Colonel looks up, stares across the river in amazemen

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: How the hell did he get over there?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: standing on the opposite bank, yelling.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What the hell are you waiting for?!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Looking for a place to ford, General. I sent out a patrol to reconnoiter.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I've already done that. Down by those trees this sewer's only three feet deep. (lashing out) You get that outfit cranked up or you're going so be out of a job!  66 220 221 222 223 72

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (quaking) Yes, sirl

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (roaring) And put that helmet on! Fumbiing for his helmet, the Colonel hastens to comply.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN INFANTRY
dialogues.text: An infantry platoon rises up from positions of cover and moves forward. Almost immediately they are taken under heavy machine-gun fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DaY In the tiny room there are Patton and Stiller; a shattere LISUTENANT COLONEL, who is battalion commander; a Major, who is his executive; and a communications SERGEANT. Patton is taking the hide off the Lieutenant Colonel, who is trying to defend himself.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT COLONEL
dialogues.text: The reason we're pinned down, General, is we can't get any air support.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The hell with that! Nobody's getting air support! (raging) If you can't put some fire under this battalion, Colonel, by God we'll find somebody who can! (jabbing a forefinger at the Major) I'm putting you in command, Major! (fiercely) I'll give you four hours -- and if you don't break through to that beachhead, I'll fire youl Patton turns and stalks out, followed by Stiller.

dialogues.speaker: . SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Colonel, there are fifty thousand men on this island who'd like to shoot that sonuvabitch.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSKIRTS SMALL TOWN IN CENTRAL SICILY
dialogues.text: A mechanized artillery outfit -- guns, trucks, weapons, etc. -- is stalled and bunched up on the road leading Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 73 223 Cont. 22k 225 226 227 into the little town, making a perfect target for air attack. Patton's command car barrels into scene and he is livid when he sees the vulnerable column of motionless equipment. He yells to a SERGEANT in a weapons carrier.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (roaring) what's holding up this column?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (appalled when he recognizes the apoplectic face of Patton) I -- I don't know, sir -- From o.s. there is the sound of approaching aircraft. Patton glances up, then gives his driver a poke in the back. —

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Let's go. The driver pulls the car off onto the shoulder of the roa and roars ahead, steeving an expert but dangerous course between the stalled colvmn and the steep ditch beside th: road. The roar of the planes is almost overhead now.

dialogues.speaker: TWO HEINAEL FIGHTER-BOMBERS
dialogues.text: The German planes open up with their machine guns.

dialogues.speaker: THE STALL
dialogues.text: as the planes strafe the entire length of the sitting duck column, Men scatter and some are cut down. Patton's command car continues to skirt the edge of the road at top speed,

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S COMMAND CAR
dialogues.text: Machine-gun fire spatters all around it. The driver duc‘c down as best he can. Codman and the others are on the floor. But Patton is still standing, his jaw jutting in angry defiance.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his voice cool) Pull up over there.

dialogues.speaker: AVGLE IN BRIDGE
dialogues.text: This is a narrow bridge leading into the tiny town. On the bridge we see what is holding up the column. A cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 ans 227 Cont. 228 229 230 231 232 SICILIAN PEASANT, alternately crying and shouting, is trying to coax a team of donkeys attached to his cart to move off the bridge so the machinery of war can get acros An exasperated MAJOR, along with a couple of noncoms, tri to aid in moving the donkeys. Suddenly Patton is upon them.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR
dialogues.text: Sir, it's these mules --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (furious) They're jackasses}! You let a whole column get stalled and strafed on account of a couple of jackasses? What the hell's the matter with you? Before the Sicilian has time to do more than cry out in protest, Patton has drawn his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He fires twice, There is a scream of anguish from the Sicilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The donkeys now lie motionless on the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (to the Major and his men) Don't just stand there! Dump them in the river! The men move to obey, pushing the heavy corpses over the side.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE WATER
dialogues.text: as the beasts hit the river. We see in the reflection that the column is moving again.

dialogues.speaker: UP ANGLE
dialogues.text: They bank into a steep turn to come back for another pass at the helpless column,

dialogues.speaker: WING GUNS
dialogues.text: The machine euns clatter as they go into their second strafing run.  66 233 23k 235 236 237 238 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The column is gathering speed as it clatters across the bridge. The planes roar over, but the moving equipment is harder to hit. Patton stands alone at the side of the bridge, oblivious to the machine-gun fire stitching the area around him, impatiently waving the vehicles across and urging them to greater speed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, ROAD IN CENTRAL SICILY
dialogues.text: On the bright sunlit road Patton's vehicles, returning from the front, have slowed to avoid a truck convoy heade toward the front. On the other side of the road, headed back, is a straggling line of GIs, the walking wounded, interspersed with an occasional ambulance and even a litter carried by mud-and-blood-encrusted medics. They are in strange and shocking contrast to Patton's shiny, polished car with its colorful banners and insignie, which overtakes them going in the same direction.

dialogues.speaker: WALKING WOUNDED
dialogues.text: Their wounds covered with temporary blood-soaked bandages the men bearded and gaunt, bone-weary and numb with pain. Those whose eyes are bandaged are led by others. Those with leg wounds are given support by their fellows, Crude splints, improvised crutches and slings are every- where. The men stare hollow-eyes at the Patton vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: His face remains hawklike and unyielding, but something in his eyes indicates the twinge of guilt and sympathy he is unwilling to reveal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One is naked to the waist, his chest heavily bandaged. The other is hobbling along, with the aid of an improvise erutch, on a badly shattered foot. They stare up at Patton, who is passing by slowly.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST WOUNDED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: There he goes -- 'old blood and guts.'

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WOUNDED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Yeah -- our blood and his guts.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, ROAD
dialogues.text: Shooting over Patton's shoulder, with his driver at the wheel. On the road up ahead is a sign with an arrow that reads: 19TH EVACUATION HOSPITAL. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 76 236 Cont. 239 243 Patton taps the driver on the shoulder, indicates with hi pointed finger that he is to follow the arrow, The drivar starts to turn off the road.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton is walking down the aisle, accompanied by a Medica Corps COLONEL, the Ward Surgeon and the ever-present Codm The patients here are all badly wounded. Some are amputze some have bandages covering their entire faces, some are - getting plasma. Patton stops by each bed with a word fo each man. We can't hear what he's saying until: Camera moves in on Patton as he stops by one of the beds, occupied by a MEXICAN-AMERICAN SOLDIER. Patton glances at the name tag on the bed,

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Where'd you get it, Gomez?

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN-AMERICAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (weakly) In the chest, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You might be interested in this -- the last German I saw had no chest and no head either. (pats his arm) Get well quickly, son. Moving on, Patton has to pause as a mobile stretcher is pushed by. On it is a man's body, covered completely by a sheet. Patton moves on to a bed where a soldier lies pale and motionless under an oxygen mask. The man is unconscious and he is breathing heavily and with difficul His entire upper body is heavily bandaged. Patton turns to Godman with a gesture, and Codman produces a Purple Heart medal out of a briefcase he carries. Patton pins the medal onto the pillowcase of the unconscious soldier. Then he kneels beside the boy's bed, takes off his helmet and bows his head in prayer for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: INDIVIDUAL REACTIONS
dialogues.text: The Colonel, a nurse, a medical corpsman. The gesture is so corny and improbable that they each stare, even though moved, stunned and disbelieving. Is this the Patton they've heard so much about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Patton rises and moves on. He comes upon a young GI sitting on a bed fully clothed, wearing a helmet liner, with no sign of a dressing or a wound. Patton eyes him suspiciously. Cont.  @ 243 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What's the master with you? ‘GI I -- I guess I just can't take it, sir, The boy begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: GI
dialogues.text: Sir, it's my nerves. I can't stand the shelling anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his voice rising) Your nerves hell] You're just a goddamn coward! The soldier actually starts crying now and Patton slaps him hard across the face.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: @ Shut up! I won't have e yellow bastard sit here crying in front of these brave men who've been wounded in battle. Patton strikes the man again. The man's helmet liner falls off and rolis across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {shouting now at the top of his lungs) Don't admit this yellow bastard. There's nothing the matter with him, I don't want sonsuvbitches who haven't the guts to fight stinking up this place of honor. (to soldier) You're going back to the front} You may get shot and killed, but you're going back to fight. Hither that or I'll stand you up in front of a firing squad! His right hand drops to his holster.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: } I ought to shoot you myself, you VY goddamn whimpering coward! Cont. 66  78 243 Cont.1 A team of medical officers quickly takes the sobbing boy away.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {screaming) . Send him up to the front. You hear me,.e. goddamn coward! Patton suddenly realizes that everyone in the tent is staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I won't have cowards in my army!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley sits in the sunlight under the makeshift awning of his trailer. Patton's command car drives up and Bradley rises to meet him. Still strained and apprehensiv Patton doesn't get out.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I had to kick some butts up there, but Truscott finally broke through to those people on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: ERADLEY
dialogues.text: {unable to resist; evenly) You get -the casualty reports?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his face momentarily clouding) Yeah -- I got 'em. (impatiently) What's the latest on the coast road?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: The 3rd Division's east of Brolo, heading toward Messina.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The hell you say! (with sudden elation) Let's get dressed up and go over there. I want to go in with the troops!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: You go ahead, George. I'm not very good at that. Patton glances at him, looking for implied criticism, but finds none, After a moment, defensively: Cont.  66 719 24 Cont. 2k5 2u6

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I know about the casualties we took. But if we hadn't made that end run, God knows how many more we would have had. Patton signals to his driver, who pulls the car out fast. Bradley watches it disappear, is turning back to his trailer when Hansen comes into scene carrying a typewritt sheet.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Sir, General Kean wanted you to see this... It's about General Patton. {handing message to Bradley It came in to the surgeon from the CO of the One hundred Forty-ninth Evacuation Hospital. Bradley looks over the report and his face goes grave.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Anyone else see this?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: No, sir -- just General Kean and the surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Put it in an envelope and lock it up in my sefe.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Bradley hands the message back to Hansen, shakes his heai gravely. Then as Hansen starts away: .

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Chet -- mark it to be opened only by you or me,

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: In the turret of the leading tank of an armored column stands Patton, his polished helmet shining, looking every inch the conquering hero, The clatter of armor as the column races across the peaceful countryside toward Messina brings excitement to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, A ROAD OUT OF CATANIA, (EAST COAST OF SICILY)
dialogues.text: A British convoy moves along the road northward to Messin General Montgomery stands along the roadside, smiling ani Cont.  “ 66 80 246 Cont. 2h7 28 returning the friendly waves of his men. We notice that in contrast with the American troops the men of the Eight Army dress any way they please. Because of the heat, most of them are half naked. One of the enlisted men shouts out as his tank passes the sweater-wearing General.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Hello, there, Monty.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Hello, yourself. Another vehicle has a driver who is absolutely naked and wears a silk top hat. He laughingly tips his hat to his General. Montgomery breaks out into laughter; then, after that vehicle passes, turns to his Aide dryly:

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Issue an order: Henceforth, top hats will not be worn by members of the Eighth Army. Another vehicle full of cheering men passes.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BRITISH SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Fifty kilometers to Messina, Monty! He waves back, smiling and nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Highland Pipers strut proudly toward the main square of the bomb-damaged town, their pipes blaring. Montgomery's command car is behind them. They round a corner, then stop, the wind in the bags remaining for a dissonant moment. Montgomery climbs out of his car, takes a few steps forward so he can look around the corner. MONTGOMERY'S P.0.V. Patton, with folded arms, standing before the town hall, packed by his nattily uniformed staff: Stiller, Codman, Bell, Davenport, Carver. Ali about the square are America vehicles'and men. Patton wears a triumphant smile on his face. Montgomery approaches Patton.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Don't smirk, Patton, I shan't kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: That's a pity, because I shaved very close this morning in preparation for getting smacked by you. Cont.  66 81 248 Cont. 29

dialogues.speaker: A-29
dialogues.text: Montgomery smiles and salutes. Patton returns it smartly. The pipers begin their tune once again as Montgomery turn and moves back toward his vehicle. our

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The bar is full of soldiers, all neatly uniformed, Patton fashion, and there are plenty of MPs in evidence. A reporter nemed LARRY DOYLE, in correspondent's uniform, is being half-led, half-dragged to the bar by a big, LOUDMOUTHED GI.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Here's the man you're looking for, Mr. Doyle. He's my buddy and he was there! Saw the whole thing! (to a quiet, diffident man having a drink with another G1) Go on -- tell him, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You actually saw this happen?

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (before he can answer Saw it? He was right in the next bed! Patton took ons look at this GI, hauled off and hit him across the face! (jumping around as he acts it out) Then he grabs him and kicks hin. But hard. Knocked him ass over teakettle. :

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (getting his oar in) All the time he was calling him every dirty name in the book.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: Were you there, too?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
dialogues.text: No -- Charlie told us.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Then he took out his guns and threatened to shoot this guy! Cont.  82 A-249 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (to Quiet Soldier) He actually threatened to shoot him?

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: ( jumping in) Would I lie to you?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (trying to sideslip Loudmouth ) Charlie -- what do you think they should do to General Patton for this?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
dialogues.text: They oughta give him a medical discharge. He's mentally deranged.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: When you've got Patton, who needs Hitler?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I'm asking him.

dialogues.speaker: QUIET SOLDIER
dialogues.text: If he wants to kick me in the ass a few times, it's all right with me. I think Patton'll get me home safe.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (impatiently) He'll get you home in a box!

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (the broken record) If you ask ms, they oughta give him e medical discharge.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDMOUTHED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Who the hell asked you? You weren't even there! 250 pe PATTON'S PALAZZO HEADQUARTERS IN PALERMO - MED. SH A . In f.g. Patton sits slumped in a huge chair, his face clouded in deep depression. His very motionlessness is in stark contrast to his usual kinetic energy. One lifeless hand, holding a letter, rests in his lap. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 83 250 Cont. a In b.g. Bradley is admitted by Codman, who gestures Bradley in silently, then goes out himself, Bradley moves forward, a little puzzled by Patton's failure to turn and greet him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, George?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (lifelessly) I've got a letter here from Ike. He hands the letter to Bradley without looking up. As Bradley starts to read the letter, Patton speaks in a strained, making-conversation tone.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I was rereading Caesar's ‘Commentaries! the other night. In battle, Caesar wore a red robe so he would be clearly distinguishable from his men. I was struck by this fact because -= (he suddenly pauses, © sWallows; we sense he's been kicked in the stomach) 'Despicable'... (closing his eyes in pain First time in my life anybody ever applied that word to me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (looking up, gently) At least it's a personal reprimand -~ not official.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (suddenly, violently) That man was yellow! Should have been tried for cowardice and shot! (then, just as suddenly, confused) Have they forgotten about all the people who are getting a hell of 6 lot worse than a little kick in the pants?... I ruffled his pride a little, What's that compared to war?,.. Two weeks ago, When we took Palermo, I was a hero -- the greatest general since Stonewall Jackson. Now they draw cartoons about me -- the dirty bastards. Cont,  © 66 250 Cont.1 251 252 253 254. PATTON (Cont.) (hands a newspaper clipping to Bradley) They've got me holding a little GI and kicking him with an iron boot. {his rage and resentment building) You see what's on that boot? A swastika! On my boot! An iron boot with a swastika on it! He takes the letter from Bradley, slumps back in his chair, reads in a dead, lifeless voice. _ ‘PATTON ',.. you will apologize to the soldier you slapped, so all doctors and nurses who were present in the tent, to every patient who can be reached, and last but not least, to the Seventh Army as a whole, through individual units, one at a time.' Bradley looks at Patton with genuine sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: FATTON
dialogues.text: God, I feel low.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton kneels, praying, in the nave in front of a huge Byzantine marble candleholder. The morning sunlight stabs through the windows of the dome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton rises and we see that he is dressed in his typical magnificence. He isaves the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men of Patton's commend are gathered outside. They immediately become silent as Patton's impressive figure strides across the entrance to the head of a broad stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Patton proceeds to the center, we see the faces of young GIs watching him. We see the nurses, the doctors who had been present in the tent.  255 256 257- 25 66 85

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He looks over the men intently, takes a deep breath, pull himself to his full height.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I thought I'd stand up here and let you fellows see if I'mas big a sonuvabitch as some of you think I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Digarmed, the GIs go wild! First, with laughter, then with cheers. This pleases Patton. He finally holds his hands up for silence.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with quiet dignity) I assure you I had no intention of being either harsh or cruel in my treatment of the soldier in question. My sole purpose was to try and restore in him some appreciation of his obligations as a man and & soldier. If one can shame a coward, I felt, one might help him regain his self- respect... It was this I had in mind -- though I admit freely now that my method was wrong... I hope you will understand my motive -- and will accept this explanation and this apology... Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: STIRS HEATED CONTROVERSY
dialogues.text: A. MED. SHOT - WOMAN aT PODIUM A middle-aged WOMAN speaks before half a dozen micro- phones,

dialogues.speaker: O68.
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hilda Scott, National President of Mothers for America, gives us the women's point of view:

dialogues.speaker: MRS, SCOTT
dialogues.text: As a woman, I think that monster Patton should be thrown out of the Army! As a mother, I demand it! Cont.  86 257- Cont. 259
Congressional opinion is sharply divided, Debating the subject here is Representative William Shaw, of Omaha, Nebraska:

dialogues.speaker: REPRESENTATIVE SHAW
dialogues.text: (shaking his jowls he takes his stand) My friends, if you have a good thoroughbred racehorse that bites and kicks the stableboy, but wins a race for you every Saturday, you'd be crazy to take him out and shoot him, wouldn't you? He waits for and gets his applause. Meanwhile:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.8.) This point of view is opposed by Congressman Sam Buckman, of California. Camera executes a hand-held pan to another Congressman standing at a similar lectern across the stage.

dialogues.speaker: REPRESENTATIVE BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: I say to you, ladies and gentlemen, that we happen to care about our stableboys! We think they're worth a good deal more than winning a horse race! There is wild applause. (NOTE: END OF NEWSREEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves ahead of Patton and Meeks as they move throu a series of offices toward Patton's private office.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: It is my belief, Meeks, that the temple we saw today marks the spot where Hasdrubal committed suicide in 397 B.C., and that the Greeks built that temple to celebrate the act. But when the Carthaginians came back, they destroyed it.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: On second thought, I am not sure if it was Hasdrubal or the old Hannibal. Anyhow, when he saw that the battle was lost, he jumped on the funeral pyre. They ‘have arrived in Patton's private office, where Codm is arranging a tray on which he has an ice bucket with bottle of champagne and several glasses. He is trans-~ ferring a pile of envelopes from the tray to Patton's des

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Good evening, General. Just want to make a report on a private poll I've been taking.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What poll?

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: The fan mail. Eleven percent 'con' -- eighty-enine percent 'pro'. That eleven percent of protest in most cases are both obscene and anonymous. But the 'pro' letters are mostly from relatives and servicemen. (picking one up, reading:) 'I want you to know that we are proud our son is serving in your Army. From the newspaper account, we are not clear as to exactly what you did, and why, but we want you to know we are for you. Keep going, and God bless you.'!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (morosely) ‘Keep going! where? Cont.  88 260 Cont. During the above, Meeks has withdrawn. CcODMA’ {trying to cheer him up) I thought you might like a sip of wine, General... It's New Year's Day -- and you didn't celebrate at all last night.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I'm fed up with sitting here in this royal doghouse. We've taken Sicily. I'm ready for a new assignment.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you've got it. (taking an envelope from the tray) Here's a radio message just came in.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (before opening the envelope, his ambition clear) The one coming up is the big job. Command of all American troops for the European invasion. Patton opens the envslope and reads the message. He is quite literally stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Cod -- I've bven relieved, (unable to accept it) They've relieved me from command of Seventh Army.

dialogues.speaker: GODMAN
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. Patton hands him the message.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (grimly) Happy New Year}

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, sir. If they were going to give you another command, isn't it logical that they'd relieve you here first?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (wondering if he dare share Codman's optimism) 66 You mean the invasion command? Cont.  Oo 66 89 260 Cont.1 261 Codman nods.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Well -- it's possible -- (dying to believe) I know it's been discussed fram time to time.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: The logic of it is so obvious. It couldn't mean anything elseJ (with sudden enthusiasm) Sir, I'm going to open this bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (Codman's enthusiasm is contagious) By God, I'm going to help you drink itl

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The drapes are drawn and Meeks has laid out Patton's uniform for tomorrow. Meeks himself is seated by the bed, gravely polishing the already-shining helmet. As Patton enters, Meeks rises, studying him with unobtrusive concern. But Patton is in good spirits, buoyed up by the wine and by his renewed hopes. .

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: (watching him closely) How you feeling, General?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Not bad. Not bad at all. (sitting on bed) Get me some writing paper, will you, George.

dialogues.speaker: . MEEKS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. PaTToy (pulling off one shoe) Your wits ever give you tne devil for not writing?

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: All the time. But I don'ts write as often as you do. Just can't get around to it. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 261 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Lucky thing for us that we've got teme (grinning, he pulls off the other shoe) Who the hell would want to marry a couple of proken-down horse cavalrymen?

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: That's what my wife says to me every time I come home. Patton has risen and crossed to the French doors leading to a balcony. He glances at a clock on the mantel as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: George, What are you doing up this late?

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: (evasively) I just thought you might like a nice hot bath or a glass of milk or something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Patton steps out to inhale the sweet night air, Meeks appears behind him from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: I got a sleeping pill from the doc w- just in case you need it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Sleeping pill?... Say, what's going on here

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: {he thinks Patton is concealing his real feelings) General, we all heard the news tonight. They announced it on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What news?

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: You know. About General Bradley. How they gave him the top American command for the invasion. 66 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 gL 262 Cont. 263 This hits Patton right between the eyes, shattering utter the optimistic dream he built up with Codman. He looks wounded and pale.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Oh... Oh, yeah --

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: I figured you might be feeling kind of low -- Unable to reply, Patton simply shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND MEEKS
dialogues.text: Feeling utterly helpless, Meeks gestures toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: Your writin' things are on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No, I -- I won't be writing tonight. Acutely aware of Patton's suffering, Meeks is deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: (loyaliy resentful, he shakes his head) One little dogface -- one measly little slap -- that's what done it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (suddenly venting his emotions Oh, George -- I wish I'd kissed the sonuvabitch!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The sweeping lawn looks out over the Roman sea wall, the old port and the colorful city itself. Gathered on the lawn are the middle-aged ladies and gentlemen of the upper-crust French colony. Standing on the landing of a sweeping flight of steps, Patton is addressing them in Prench.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Nous rendons hommage aux superbes forces de la France Libre menses par le General De Gaulle et le General Leclerc. Et n'oublions pas les heros, hommes et femmes, de la Resistance, qui risquent leur vie chaque jour pour vaincre le Boche. Camera has pulled back, leaving Patton, and centers ona group of four or five CORRESPONDENTS gathered around Codman, Who is translating for them.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: {his eye on Patton) He is paying tribute to the Free French forces under De Gaulle and Leclerc. Also to the brave men and women of the Resistance who risk their lives every day to help destroy the Germans,

dialogues.speaker: PATTON CODMAN
dialogues.text: La France redeviendra (keeping an eye libre -- je vous en donne on Patton, translating) ma parole! Tout comme 'France Will be free agaia -- les troupes de la France I give you my word. Just as Libre ont debarque ici en Free French troops landed Corse pour liberer la terre here in Corsica to liberate natale de Napoleon, je debarquerai bientot en I will land someday in France et aiderai a la Prance and help liberate the liberation de la terre natale birthplace of Lafayette! de Lafayette! the birthplace of Wapoleoa,

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The conclusion of his remarks has brought enthusiastic applause. Smiling and bowing, he steps down the stairs and is accepting the warm congratulations of the local leaders as Codman comes into scene. Cont.  93 265 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: General -- the reporters would like a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch as Codman ieads Patton over to them.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: ‘afternoon, gentlemen -~-

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: General Patton, can you say anything about the purpose of this visit to Corsica?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (gruffly) I was ordered here by General Eisenhower.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: It was reported that you wrote the mother of the boy you slapped, saying: 'The yellow rat should have been shot.' Is that true, General? With a visible effort, Patton manages to control himself

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: I understand General Alexander suggested you take on General Mark Clark's ass tenment in Italy, but the War Department ilte ecause of the slapping incident. Patton glares at the correspondent but controls himself.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: Can you tell us where you'll be going from here?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: General Eisenhower has ordered me to Malta. That's off the record. Interview concluded. Patton tekes one last glaring look at the First Correspon who asked about the "yellow rat" latter, then turns away and exits. 66  267 268 ou

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Malta?

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. With a look of concern, Jodi turns to a large wall map, studies it gravely. He points first to the island of Malta, then to the coast of Greece.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Malta as a base, possibly -= then Southern Greece -- (he turns with sudden decision, picks up a phone) Get me Field Marshal Keitel.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton is acting as guide for his staff, pointing out to them the ancient fort.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: During the siege of 1528, those forts were held by four hundred Knights of Malta and eight hundred mercenaries against a force of forty. thousand Turks. As the others look off at the forts, Patton turns private to Codman. .

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Codman -- did we get any response from Ike about those two turkeys I sent him for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: No, sir. Patton motions for the others to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Go on over, gentlemen -- take a look. As the officers move off, Patton speaks to Codman, shakin his head.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you boys have hitched your wagon to a falling star... Pass the word -- if anyone wants out, I'll understand. Cont.  QO) 268 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Sir, I can speak for the entire staff. We want to stay with you, no matter what duty you're assigned.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (seething with deep, barely controllable frustration) Up in London they're planning the invasion of Europe. What the hell am I doing out here in the boondocks ? This is the moment I've trained my mind and body and spirit for. I'm a soldier! It's as natural for me to be a soldier as it is to breathe, and it would be as hard to give up as it would to stop breathing! (growling resentfully) All right, let's get on to Cairo -- see if the pyramids are still standing.

dialogues.speaker: EGYPT
dialogues.text: @ Camera pulls back to reveal Jodl talking on a phone as studies the map. Steiger is by his side.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (into phone) There is only one reason for him to be in Cairo. To confer with the Greek and Yugoslav governments in exile... Let the Italians garrison Italy, for God's sake -- it's their country. We'll need our German troops to reinforce Crete and the coast of Greece if Patton strikes from Egypt! He hangs up, concerned and preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: I have some naw information, sir. Patton is under severe criticism. He may even be court-martialed. (indicating news releases in his hand) It seems he slapped an enlisted man.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (losing patience) / Steiger, do you believe everything they put in their newspapers? Would they sacrifice their best field commander 66 because he slapped a common soldier?  270 271 272 66 96

dialogues.speaker: EXT, LONDON STREET
dialogues.text: A London bobby strolls the fog-shrouded street as a big black Packard, its headlights shielded, careens around @ corner and comes to a stop in front of a brownstone pbuilding. Patton, bundled in a heavy coat, steps out of the car, accompanied by Codman, and approaches the inconspicuous front door.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Patton and Codman enter, admitted by a CORPORAL. Patton takes a critical look about. The decor is extremely feminine, with a paneled foyer, dainty Louis XV furniture fluffy drapes and exotic prints.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (growling) This place is for me?

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. This way, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {grumbling as he follows ) Whoever found this place is a genius for cloak-and-dagger. The Corporal leads the way through the frilly hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are pink and the walis are covered with mirrors. There is a white bear rug on the parquet. The room is dominated by an enormous white bed iying low and lascivious under a fancy pink silk-embroidered coverlet. Patton looks up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire ceiling is covered with mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Codman) Who the hell picked this cathouse?

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: I believe it was Generali Smith, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He did it to spite me, the sonuvabitch! Reflected in the ceiling mirror, the image of General Bedell Smith is seen entering the room. Cont.  66 97 273 Cont. 27h

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Welcome to London, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton turns to Smith and his arrogance subsides. He is mentally exhausted and deeply apprehensive. Smith is businesslike, unbending, humorless.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Hello, Beetle. Is... is Ike here?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He asked me to brief you. (to Codman and the Corporal) Excuse us, please. Codman and the Corporal quickly take their leave, closin; the mirrored door. Smith makes himself comfortable in one of the plump chairs.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: First of all, I want to put you straight about Ike. We hear a lot about you criticizing his decisions.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No, Beetle, not really, Hell, you know I'm just a damn fool, but some- times I wonder whether he's a Limey at heart.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: George, this is the toughest coalition ever attempted in history. Ike sits on top, trying to hold it together and lick the Germans at the same time. Believe me, it's one hell of a job.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I know that. But, Beetle --

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: We have an important job for you in connection with the Normandy invasion --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I've studied the *verlord plan, and it has one serious flaw, It depends on Monty taking Caen on D-day. Well, he!'1l never make it, because it's impossibls. ['ve got a plan for another landing in the vicinity of Calais, followinr an air bombardement -- Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 27h Cont. 98

dialogues.speaker: SMITE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Please -- will you just listen for a change? And remember, Ike stuck by you when everyone -- and I mean everyone -- wanted Patton with a rope around his neck. (with finality) We're going to let it leak out that you're here under cover -- that you're preparing to invade at the Pas de Calais. We hope to pin down the German Fifteenth Army there so they can't be used against us in Normandy.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (deeply shaken) Is that all you people think i'm good for?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) We're building an army of twelve divisions around you -- ali fictitious, of course. Dummy troop concentrations, dummy landing craft and simulated radio traffic... You see, the Germans are convinced that you're going to lead the main invasion effort...The German agents will spot you here before long. Then we'll move you to your new headquarters in Knutsford.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What do I do there?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Nothing. Absolutely nothing. (rising, preparing to leave) Frankly, George, you're on probation. If you take my advice, you'll benave yourself. And remember, your worst enemy is your own big mouth.  66

dialogues.speaker: A-274
dialogues.text: 275 99 IsT, BISSAHOWSR'S HEADQUARTERS AT GROSVENOR SQUARE - MeD, SHOT + WIGHT Patton is waiting in a large anteroom what has a auiet but vigorous excitement about it. Staff officers bob out of this door, into that one. A door opens and General Bradley comes out. Patton notices him with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Brad! Bradley hes important things on his mind, but he is pleased to see his old boss.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Good to see you. How is everything? Bedell Smith sticks his head out of the office marked GENERAL EISENHOWER, beckons to Bradley.

dialogues.speaker: . SMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, General Bradley -- Bradley turns to find Smith beckoning him to come into Ike's office. This, of course, is a command.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, will you, George.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Sure, Erad. See you later -- Bradley has followed Smith into the office, leaving Patto alone and very much out of things.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TOWN OF KNUTSFORD
dialogues.text: An all-female brass band, resplendent in their Women's Land Army uniforms, is playing with a good deal more enthusiasm than talent. A large group of ladies stands outside the new Knutsford "Welcome" Club, attached to the front of which is a large red, white end blue banner reading: KNUTSFORD WELCOMES OUR AMERICAN ALLIES. The band plays The Stars and Stripes Forever as Patton's car pulls up into the crowd, which seems to be populated solely by middle-aged and older women. Patton's Packard comes to a stop by Codman who opens the door. de is surprised by a menacing white English bull terrier, who is immediately vwpon him. Patton steps out, holding the dog's leash.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Look at this nasty-faced sonuvabitch, Codman, bred for combat. I'm going to call him William, for William the Conqueror. ' Gont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 275 Cont. 276 277 278 66 The dog causes some consternation among the ladies,

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: General, maybe you'd better leave him in the car, .

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: It's all right, Codman. Good afternoon, ledies. William spots a medium-sized terrier, as does Patton.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Watch this, Cod.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: General, he'll kill that dog!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Neh, I'll hold him,

dialogues.speaker: THE TERRIER
dialogues.text: He sees William, bears his small fangs and growls menacin

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND WILLIAM
dialogues.text: William shrinks back in fear, runs around behind Patton, peering nervously from behind his leg, whining piteously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the littlest, daintiest lady stoops to pick up the terrier,

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry, General. Did Abigail frighten your poor dog?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) Quite all right, Madame. Codman smiles, eases Patton away. cODMAN This way, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (fiercely, to William, as he goes) Your name isn't William. It's Willy!  66 279 280 201

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton sits quietly with Willy on the floor by his chair, while a MRS. SMITH opens the proceedings:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMITH
dialogues.text: My dear friends, General George S. Patton, Jr. has accepted our invitation to say a few words to you in honour of this inaugural ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels a fish out of water in this frumpy and frilly environment.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMITH
dialogues.text: General Patton is not here in his official capacity. And I have assured him most earnestly that nothing he says will be quoted... May I present; General Patton. Patton rises, a little flush-faced, as the British ladies applaud. Codman leans over and whispers to him:

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Remember, sir -- watch your languags. Patton takes his place at the podiun.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: My dear ladies, until today my only experience in welcoming has been to welcome Germans and Italians to the infernal regions. In this I have been quite successful, as the troops whom I have had the honor to command have killed or captured some 170,000 of our enemies. With that the ladies go into another dainty round of applause, a few of them shouting in their meek little voices: "Hear, hear!" PaTTON I feel that such clubs as this are of very real value because I believe with Mr. Bernard Shaw that the British and the Americans are two people separated by a common language. A titter of laughter goes across the room. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: And since it is the evident destiny of the British and the Americans to rule the world, the better we know each other the better we will do. During the applause that follows, Codman leans. forward, tries to get Patton's attention.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (during the applause) The Russians! Don't forget the Russians! Patton turns but can't hear what Codman is saying because of the applause. Scowling at Codman, he turns back and proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: A club like this is an ideal place for promoting mutual understanding. As soon as our soldiers meet and know the English ladies and write home and tell our women how truly . lovely you are,the sooner the American ladies will get jealous and force this war to a quick termination. And I will then get a chance to go to the Pacific and kill Japanese. More enthusiastic applause rings through the crowd and th little ladies stand up, some on tiptoe, to honor the General, The band starts to play.

dialogues.speaker: UNION SQUARE IN NEW YORK, (STOCK)
dialogues.text: The square is filled with angry, milling protesters, some listening to speakers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) In cities all over the nation, mass meetings are held to protest General George Patton's statement that Britain and America will rule the postwar world -- that Russia will have nothing to say. Cont.  103 ey 281- Cont. ; 284.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SENATOR is seated at his desk, with an American flag on a standard behind him,

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.8-) Congressional leaders, like Senator Glaiborn Foss, are quick to react.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR FOSS
dialogues.text: This man has insulted our Russian allies, implying Anglo-American world rule. In my opinion he should be severely disciplined.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCOTT
dialogues.text: A familiar-Looking middle-aged woman speaking at a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hilda Scott, National President of Mothers for America: @ wRS,. SCOLT I still think that monster should be thrown out of the Army.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (standing before Smith's desk) Beetle, this sime I Gidn't doa damn thing! Tasy said there were no reporters there. I just made a few remarks off the record.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Ike told you to keep your mouth shut and you wouldn't listen. Don't you realize how suspicious the Russians are of the 3ritish and ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Iwas just trying to be polite to the old ladies. If they'd had any ) Russians there, I would have w mentioned them. I don't like the sonsuvbitches, but I would have ee mentioned them out of politeness. Cont.  © 66 10k. 285 Cont. 286- 25h, PATTON (Cont.) (irritated to find himself out of his element) Beetle, I don't kmow anything about politics -- you kmow that. TI have no political ambitions after the war. All I want to do is command an army in combat!

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It's out of our hands, George. Ike sent a massage last night to the Chief of Staff in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: General Marshall is a good man, a fair man.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: So now it's up to Marshall whether you stay here as a decoy or he orders you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Os. Assembled in the ports of England, the mightiest armada in military history prepares to cross the channel and assault the German-held fortress of Europe.

dialogues.speaker: A. SERIES OF CUIS
