dialogues.text: Ub Featuring the loading of LSTs and other naval craft. Tanks and vehicles of all types and sizes creak aboard the big ships.

dialogues.speaker: E. GANGPLANK OF BRITISH TROOPSHIP
dialogues.text: as Tommies in battle dress move up the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: On the dockside, he's shaking hands and laughing with some of his men as they head toward the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN TROOPSHIP
dialogues.text: Thousands of Gis wave as the ship moves out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves back from the bridge of a naval vessel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the invasion fleet pulls out.  105

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PEOVER HALL
dialogues.text: A car drives up and Patton gets out, goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT, ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: (PEOVER HALL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large foyer is cold and cavernous. Meeks comes to the door to meet Patton as he enters, takes his cap and coat. Patton's face is drawn and somber,

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: George, the war is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: It's just a matter of waiting for our orders. Meeks studies Patton's face with sympathy and concern.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I thirk I'm destined to achieve some great thing. What, I don't know. But this last incident is so trivial in its nature and so terrible in its effect that it is not the result of an accident, but the work of God.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Do you realize, George -- this may be the last great opportunity of my lifetime? Imagine -- a war involving the entire world -- and I'm left out of it! God will not permit this. T must be allowed to fulfill my destiny! (then quietly) Eis will be done. He turns and moves off across the huge lonely hall. a. BLACK AND WHITE NEWSREEL 301

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the greatest amphibious operation ever attempted, a predawn naval bombardment prepares’ the way for Allied soldiers to assault the Normandy beaches and claw out a desperate foothole on the continent of Europe. oe SERIES OF CUTS OF NAVAL SHIPS The great armada lies off’ the coast of Normandy, its guns and rockets blasting the beaches. From the troop transports landing craft are lowered to the sea, and men clamber down the cargo nets to board them.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASSAULT BEACHES
dialogues.text: oe The landing craft boil through the surf, their ramps s down and the men pour out. They struggle forward through the water, shellfire exploding all around them. A landing craft is hit but another takes its place. The men fight their way up the beach.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, C-47 AIRPLANE
dialogues.text: It is a bucket-seat job, loaded with high-priority equipm -- spare airplane parts, several propellers, a big electr generator, etc. Squeezed into the available space between the crates and heavy equipment are Patton, Codman, Meeks Willy. Beside Patton is a volume of HISTORY OF THE NORMAN CONQUEST. He has his battered Michelin road map‘out and i showing it to Codman.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I knew Monty couldn't take Caen on D-day of D plus ten, and I said so. Here they are, all hung up in this hedgerow country. What they should do now is pivot, the way von Schlieffen did on Alsace. Then we'd have a chance to do some broken field running. (tossing map aside) But they won't listen to me. (glancing about disgustedly) What a way to land on the continent of Europe. With the rest of the spare parts. (he picks up one, looks at it and throws it aside) Cont.  107 7) 308 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Sir, everything on this plane is high-priority. General dradley wouldn't send for you unless he had something in mind.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (after a moment, with deep resolve) I've learned my lesson, Cod. If I ever get another chance, so help me, I'm going to shut up end play the game. (sternly) If I forget that, you remind me! ¢ (DMAN I'll give you a ventle nudge in the ribs.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You give me a swift kick in the ass?

dialogues.speaker: CODMA.1
dialogues.text: @ (swallowing hard) Yes, sir. 309 EXT. BRADLEY'S MOBILE FIELD OFFICE IN NORMANDY - MED.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A flight of P-51s roars by overhead as Bradley's jeep, pearing Patton and Codman, Bradley's aide driving, pulls into the tented compound that makes up the command post. They are met by Hansen, who salutes sharply.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: General -- welcome to France,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope there's still a war going on, Hansen. Where's the boss?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: This way, sir. Artillery fire can be heard in the distance as Patton and Codman step out of the jeep and follow Hansen,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This new map van is half the length of a Pullman car and oy) is connected by a hinged steel deck to the 2-1/2 ton used for Bradley's living auarters. Patton, Codman and Hansen are approaching the vehicle when Montgomery, all 66 bustle and business, comes out. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Patton}! Haven't seen you since Messina!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: How are you, General?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Understand you're doing a splendid job of decoying the Jerries. ( jauntily) Forgive me -- I'm off to the front... Best of everything, old boy. (he pauses, turns) ~ By the way -- Intelligence has confirmed that I'm against Rommel again. He hurries on over to his jeep and drives off. Patton watches him go, green with envy.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Rommel. I'd love to tangle with that beautiful bastard. Bradley has appeared in the doorway of his field office.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (calling out) How are you, George?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (coming over) Pretty fair, Brad -- for a man on the dole. They shake hands and Bradley escorts him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This specially designed trailer is quite elaborate. Four plexiglass astrodomes in the roof admit daylight, and a bank of fluorescents illuminates the mapboards that run the length of the walls. There is a carpeted, mahogany- paneled office in the front, separated from the map room by a railing. It looks like the chancel of a well- appointed church.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (glancing around) This is very plush. (grinning) Looks like you're bucking for Archbishop. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 31il Cont. 109

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (aiffidently) Chet Hansen had this rig built for me. (getting down to business) George -- Ike wanted me to have a talk with you. I told him you and I could level with each other.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: We're going to activate Third Army soon as I take over 12th Army Group.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his eyes brightening) Do I get it?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: I'll be honest with you -- I've had reservations. You've been senior to me ever since I got out of the Academy. You were the boss in North Africa and Sicily. Might be a problem for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: It wouldn't bother me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: The other thing is -- (he hesitates) I don't want to hit this too hard -- but we're different kinds of people, George .--

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You're right, Brad. Goddammit, you're always right. Between my screwy ideas and your brains, we make a wonderful team. We proved that in Sicily.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Tell you the truth -- if I'd been your senior in Sicily, I would have relieved you. Cont.  © 66 311 Cont.1 110

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (pleading comes hard, but he's desperate) Brad, I'll crawl on my belly to get a command. For God's sake, gst me into the fight. The only way I can get out of the doghouse is to pull something spectacular. I have to get back in this war! My God, Hitler's own people tried to kill him two days ago. First thing you know it'll be over and -- (the thought is too awful; frankly begging) I'll keep my mouth shut. I'll be- have myself -- I give you my word, Brad. Bradley studies him for a moment. Without responding, Bradley turns to a big map on the wall, changing the subj entirely.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George, I've been working on a plan called COBRA. Like to kmow what you think of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chagrined, Patton reluctantly follows as Bradley uses the map to illustrate his remarks.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: We're slugging our way through hedgerow country half an acre a day. Have to find a way to break out. (pointing) I want to use this St.-Lo-Periers road. Let Monty pin down the enemy forces around Caen...We'd pulverize an area three and a half miles wide with saturation bombing. Follow that up with seven divisions. Then we'll have Third Army swing around and make an end run across France. (asking for a professional opinion) Well -- what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I think you need a screwball horse cavalryman to command Third Army.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY -
dialogues.text: (with a quiet grin) George -~ we came to that conclusion back in England three months ago. Cont.  66 312 Cont. 111

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You what? accusingly, as he realizes Bradley means it) Why, you dirty son of a --I (suddenly pulling himself ee I forgot. I promised to keep my mouth shut!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Rommel and Jodl are examining a large wall map of the Normandy coast, with Steiger standing by. Rommel points to several sharp salients indicated in the German defense near Coutances.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: What is this enemy activity near Coutances?

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (glancing at paper in his hand) ‘Enemy armored forces driving through our defenses at Lessay. American tank units moving at great speed, slicing through to the rear areas.'

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: (to Rommel) Excuse me, Field Marshal. This sounds very much like Patton.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (in mild annoyance) Patton is in England.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: Do we know this?

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: Normandy is merely a feint. The major invasion will come at Calais and Patton will lead it. The Fuehrer has ordered thet under no circumstances should the Fifteenth Army be moved to Normandy.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: Those men are sitting on the beach at Calais throwing pebbles at each other while our men in Normandy are being slaughtered. Cont.  C) 313 Cont. 314 315 316 317 318 319 66 112

dialogues.speaker: JODIL
dialogues.text: The Fifteenth Army is waiting for Patton at Calais and Calais is where he will land.

dialogues.speaker: ROMMEL
dialogues.text: You seem perfectly willing, Jodi, to accept this nonsense. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: {with a faint smile of superiority) Because I am not prepared, sir, to dispute the Fuehrer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanks driving forward at tremendous speed. There is an ai of excitement, of movement, of drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton's jeep driving madly along. Coming up alongside th lead tank without pausing, Patton stands in the jeep and shouts to the tank commander.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Go as far as you can, as fast as you can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting down on an armored column racing along a road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a roadblock up ahead. Slow down and I'li see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: TANK COMMANDER
dialogues.text: (into his mike) Roger. He turns to give the signal to slow down the column.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN ROADBLOCK
dialogues.text: It is built of wrecked vehicles and wooden timbers. The German soldiers, hearing the roar of advancing armor, ass positions of defense. There is the sound of a fast- approaching aircraft,  66 320 321 322 323 324 113

dialogues.speaker: P-51
dialogues.text: The plane is angled down, its wing guns firing.

dialogues.speaker: ROADBLOCK
dialogues.text: Machine-gun bullets pound the area, and some of the Germa manning the roadblock are cut down. The P-51 roars by overhead.

dialogues.speaker: ROADBLOCK
dialogues.text: as American armored column approaches, gathering speed. Two German soldiers who are not hit attempt to reposition their Panzerfaust to get a shot at the lead tank.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD TANK
dialogues.text: It does not hesitate, but crashes through the roadblock, its machine gun firing, knocking out the Panzerfaust and its crew. It races on relentlessly, followed by the other tanks.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The map section is bustling with activity now. A couple of noneoms work at celluloid-covered wall maps with sponges, trying to keep. up with Patton's advance. They alter the little red squares and circles representing German positions -- and the blue ones representing those of the Allies. General Bradley and General Bedell Smith are watching the changes recorded on the map as camera moves in to two sho of them.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You'd think George would at least have the courtesy to let us know where he's going. Bradley grins, delighted that Patton is performing so wel They are interrupted by Hansen, who hands a message to Bradley.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, General, there's a heavy German counterattack aimed at Mortain. Five panzer and SS divisions have penetrated the First Army front.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (his face serious as he studies the message) Keep me posted on this, Chet.  w 66 325

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: 1uy

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Steiger -- now a major -- watches as Jodl studies a wall map showing the German advance toward Mortain. (It is the equivalent of the map in A SOLDIER'S STORY, page 373.)

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (elated as he studies the map) This offensive was a stroke of military genius. And remember -- it was ordered by the Fuehrer -- not by the Army! (pointing to deep German penetration) This attack isolates the British from the Americans. We will drive them piecemeal back into the sea. (motioning north with the back of his hand) Montgomery this way -- (sweeping south and west with his palm) Bradley and Patton this way.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: But we don't even know where Patton is?

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A column of troops is marching by as Bradley and Hansen, ina jeep, scan the countryside looking for someone. Suddenly Hansen points to a section of the marching colum

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: There he is, sir. In that column --

dialogues.speaker: MARCHING COLUMN
dialogues.text: In the column of GIs marching at route step is Patton. He's talking to the men with great interest -- and listening just as intently. After a moment, Hansen's voice can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Patton -- ! Patton looks up, sees Bradley. With a nod to the marching soldiers, he moves out to join Bradley, camera following him to Bradley's jeep.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (to Bradley) This one outfit's been dragging its tail, and I came up here to find out why... Men are tired, that's all -- and they're badly led. I'll put a new commander in here and they'll be fine. Cont.  ©

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George, we've got the German attack pretty well stopped at Mortain. I believe we can turn this pocket into a trap if we move fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You give me the word and I'll drive north to Falaise.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: No -- I want you to go as far as Argentan and hold there. Montgomery's Canadians will come on down and close the gap.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He's not set for it -- and I am. We can mousetrap a whole German Army in that pocket, but if we wait for Monty, they'll get away...Brad, if those Germans escape, we'll only have to fight them again someplace else. BRADLEY . Don't you think I realize that, George?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Then let me nail them.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: There'll be nineteen German divisions trying to bust out of that trap. You'd be stretched too thin. Be- sides, you might run into our own bombing. (with quiet but final authority) I want you to build up a solid shoulder at Argentan and hold there - understand?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (controlling the explosion within him) Yes, sir -- goddemmit!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Patton is fencing with a young BRITISH LIAISON OFFICER. {Perhaps saber would be more interesting and effective than foils.) Patton is more expert than the Englishman -- and much more aggressive. He slashes awey, always on the attack -- never parries. Jilly is lying on the floor watching the fencers. Bell enters the room, not at all surprised at what is going on. Cont.  66 326 Cont. 116

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What is it? (still -fencing) Your guard, Phillips!

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: Sir, the Canadians have already advanced by one-half mile.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (slashing away at his opponent) Half a mile? What the hell is Monty doing? Cexasperated, to the Britisher) I could kill every damn Kraut in that pocket if I didn't have to sit here and wait for that boss of yours...I'd drive the British back into the sea for another Dunkirk. Why doesn't Monty just attack?! (slashing aggressively) That's what I do -- I attack!... Atways attack! He's driven his opponent back almost to the. wall.

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: Sir, Field Marshal Rommel's car was hit today in a strafing attack by one of our planes. He was very badly wounded. Patton stops fencing, slowly lowers his saber. After a moment, he growls:

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Hope he pulls through -- the sonuvabitch. Obviously moved and disturbed by this news, he tosses his saber aside, speaks with sudden determination:

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Bell -- get General Bradley on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (insistently) Brad -- instead of sitting on my rosy butt waiting for Monty, why can't I get moving again? There's nothing out front -- nothing between me and the Seine!... My intelligence people tell me there's hardly any German strength between Vitre and the Loire. And the bridge at Angers is still intact.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Can you hold that shoulder and still move forward?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Hell, I can leave two divisions here to wait for Monty and I can be across the Seine in a weekl... Whatts thet? I can't hear you, Brad --!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) I said get moving}

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of tanks roars down the road and into camera at high speed, mud flying in ail directions.

dialogues.speaker: SUPPLY TRUCKS
dialogues.text: careening down highway. In the b.g. we see more columns of tanks, There is movement everywhere,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Columns of mud-spattered vehicles moving forward, compani of infantry plodding on through the wet. One GI looks up and turns to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: GI
dialogues.text: Good God, look at that!

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEZ
dialogues.text: Their first view of Patton in combat. He is standing up in his command car, his attire all spit and polish. on Cont.  © 116 334 Cont. 335 336 337 338 339 340

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his hips are the pistols, on his head the polished helmet Even the command car manages to remain immaculate and shiny. One GI shouts out to him:

dialogues.speaker: GI
dialogues.text: Where you going, General? Patton turns, smiles. PaTTON . To Berlint I'm personally going to shoot that paper-hanging sonuvabitch!

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN TANK PLATOON
dialogues.text: They are firing from a hull-down position behind a little rise.

dialogues.speaker: MED. SHO
dialogues.text: It is hit and blown up.

dialogues.speaker: ON ROAD
dialogues.text: German infantry troops are being herded to the rear by GI

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER HEADLINE
dialogues.text: The headline reads: PATTON DASHES ACROSS FRANCE

dialogues.speaker: THIRD ARMY BAGS 20,000 GERMANS
dialogues.text: Camera pulls back to reveal the paper in the hand of Bradley. With a broad grin on his face, Bradley hands the paper over to Hansen.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Give George a headline and he's good for another thirty miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton's armor roars past as a column of German soldiers, hands behind their necks, trudge in the opposite directio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steiger is keeping his own score of the German casualties inflicted by Patton's army, He has a piece of opaque plastic on his desk, on which has been printed in crayon the word CASUALTIES. Under this is the following:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTURED . . . . 16,119
dialogues.text: Gont,.  66 119 340 Cont. 3hl 343 3bh Steiger erases the 16, 119 figure with a cloth and substitutes 18,563.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American half-track with General Carver in it pulls up alongside a lead tank. Carver shouts to the tank COMMANDE ‘CARVER Have you lost contact with the enemy?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: Well, move up after them!

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: (grinning) We bypassed them, General. They're behind us!

dialogues.speaker: IN
dialogues.text: working on his chart again. It now reads:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTURED. . . 16,563
dialogues.text: He is rubbing out the 18,563 figure and substituting 34,1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of Third Army tanks stopped. Several tank COMMANDERS are squatting around their maps.

dialogues.speaker: TANK COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Hell, it just isn't on the map!

dialogues.speaker: TANK COMMANDER
dialogues.text: You know why? We've run clear off the map.

dialogues.speaker: -INT. REICHSCHANCELLERY
dialogues.text: His chart now reads:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTURED, . . 34,104
dialogues.text: He is rubbing out the 34,10 figure and substituting in crayon 62,163.  66

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton and Codman are ina jeep as it moves down the road. They are looking up into the sky end Patton is talking into a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: ON LIGHT RECON PLANE
dialogues.text: as it circles overhead.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Still looking up, Patton yells orders into the microphone and gestures toward a halted tank column beside the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several small parachutes blossom open below the circling plane and drop to the ground. Camera pans down as tank commanders rush to open the tubular packets attached to the chutes. Maps are unrolled and the tank commanders remount their vehicles. In a few moments the tank engines are roaring as they speed onward again.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S JEEP
dialogues.text: There is a broad triumphant grin on Patton's face as the jeep roars past the tank column. The tankers wave and grin back es Patton passes. On his face, as he feels the thrill of this hell-for-leather dash, is an expression close to ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Several ambulances are trying to cross the main road, and & heavy traffic snarl has developed, Two tanks are slithering around in the mud, their treads getting no traction, adding to the confusion, An MP knee-deep in mud is trying to unsnarl the traffic, but he's not gettin anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: His face is grim as he sees the traffic snarl below.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (to Pilot) Take me down to that foul-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it circles and proceeds to land in a field adjoining the crossroads.  66 35k 355

dialogues.speaker: TRAFFIC SNARL
dialogues.text: Tanks, ambulances, half-tracks are in a welter of confusi Drivers are yelling pointlessly and the MP is hopelessly out of his depth. Patton bursts on the scene like a tornado, yells at the MP.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Get out.of the way! I'1l unscramble this mess! As he backs away from the rampaging Patton, the MP stumbles and fails into a mud puddle, getting soaking wet

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY'S JEEP
dialogues.text: Bradley and Hansen are in the jeep as it approaches the traffic jam and slows down. Bradley surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: TRAFFIC JAM
dialogues.text: Wallowing through the mud, Patton has jumped up on 4 gasoline drum that is in water up to half its height. Yelling directions we cannot make out but are clearly blistering, he manages to pull order out of the chaos and get the column moving again.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Passing the MP, who is wet and shaking with cold, Bradley motions Hansen to stop, takes off his field jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Chet, take this over to that boy. I can get another one a lot easier than he can.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The roaring lash of his tongue having broken the log jam, he now directs traffic with the magnificent grace of a Roman policeman. He is interrupted by Hansen, who salutes and reports that Bradley wants to see him. (The roar of the vehicles drowns out all dialogue.) Turning the traffi control back to the MP, Patton leaps down from his gasoli drum, moves over to join Bradley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Patton approaches, salutes.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: You'd make e good traffic cop. (then, seriously) George, this drive to the Seine has been absolutely magnificent. But I'm sorry to say we have to slow you down. Cont.  © 66 357 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What the hell for?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: For the time being we have to cut off your supplies -- gasoline, ammunition, everything. SHAEF is up against a new set of priorities.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his suspicions growing heated) I think I smell Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Now take it easy, George. There are serious issues involved here -- political issues.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (belligerently) By God it is Montgomery!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: The launchins sites for the V-2 bombs are all in his area. And Mr. Churchill wants those rocket bases destroyed. Hitler's killing more civilians in London than soldiers in the field!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {disdainfully) They expect Monty to do anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: He said if he was given the supplies, he'd pounce on them like a savage wolf.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: He'll pounce like a savage rabbit! (angrily) You give me that gasoline and I'll gain ground with it. I'll kill Germans, too. Give me 400,000 gallons and I'll go to Berlin!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George, I can't do it, Cont.  66 357 Cont.1 123

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: That Siegfried line is an empty shell -- don't you realize that? They've stripped it and sent all the equipment to the eastern front. It's overgrown and crawling with cows. I could poke through it in two days:

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (his patience running out) No use arguing with me. This wasn't my idea.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What did you pick me to command for if you won't let me kill Germans?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (finally exasperated and angry) I didn't pick you! Ike picked you! «eeXou've performed brilliantly -- you're loyal and dedicated. You're one of the best field commanders I have, but you don't know when to shut up... George, you're a pain in the neck!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (taken aback, he quiets down) Itve got a lot of faults, Brad -- I kmow that’ -- but ingratitude isn't one of them. And I owe you a lot... Hell, I know I'm a prima donna -- I admit it! What I hate about Monty is that he won't admit it! 358 INT. PATTON'S COMMAND POST (ACROSS THE SEINE) - MED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton is lecturing his Third Army staff, including the familiar faces of Carver, Davenport, Bell, Codman, Stille Willy is at Patton's feet. .

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I will not allow Third Army to sit on its ass! I want you to round up every drop of gas and every bit of ammunition you can find. Drain and deadline all supply vehicles. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 12h 358 Cont. 359 360 361 PATTON (Cont.) Ground the spotter planes... Go on out and get gasoline -- I don't care how you get it. We'll move forward till our engines go dry ~- then we'll fight on foot! Remember, this isn't the War College -- this is Third Army!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A nattily dressed Military Policeman stands in the inter- section, holding up his hand to stop the lead truck of a convoy with FIRST ARMY on their bumpers. An MP LIEUTENANT, standing beside a temporary sign readin FIRST ARMY GASOLINE DEPOT, calls out to the DRIVER of the lead truck.

dialogues.speaker: MP LIBUTENANT
dialogues.text: Is that First Army gasoline?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MP LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: {jabbing his thumb in direction indicated by sign) Detour... This way. The MP in the intersection signals gracefully the indicat direction, and the truck convoy moves out. After the last truck has passed, the MP Lieutenant reaches up and peels off a piece of masking tape on the sign that bears the word FIRST, leaving the sign as it was originally -- THIRD ARMY GASOLINE DEPOT. The MP exchanges a erin with his Lieutenant. . Lieutenant -- worl get the bronze star for this.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A column of four tanks moves down the road.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND TANK
dialogues.text: The tank's engine sputters, coughs and dies. The vehicle stops and the crew gets out. The third and fourth tanks slow down and the men clamber aboard.  66 362 363 364~ 36 367 368 369 370 371 372 373 125

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Down the road comes an unlikely caravan -- a tank towing an ammunition truck, behind which is fastened a weapons carrier, which in turn hes a 105mm howitzer attached to i

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A tank unit is moving across the field in line. Half have run out of gas, and as we watch, five or six sputter and come to a stop. Ths crews get out with their weapons and move forward on foot.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Quick flashes of tanks stopped in odd positions, shot fro odd angles. They look like frozen frames -- one tank stalled climbing a ditch, another fording a little stream another on the side of a hill.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Three American tanks move across the field.

dialogues.speaker: TANK COMMANDER
dialogues.text: He's a CAPTAIN, a big man who fills the hatch as he scans the darkness ahead through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of German armored vehicles can be seen in the darkness moving along a road.

dialogues.speaker: THREE AMERICAN TANKS
dialogues.text: They are headed toward the road. The third tank coughs, sputters and stops as its engine dies.

dialogues.speaker: TANK COMMANDER, (SERGEANT)
dialogues.text: He speaks into his microphone.

dialogues.speaker: TANK COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Captain -- Bailey's run out of gas and there's a Kraut column up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (quietly, into his mike) I know... Button up and open fire soon as you find a target.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN TANKS
dialogues.text: They open fire, their gun flashes piercing the night.  66 374 375 376 377 378 379 360 361 126

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN ARMORED COLUMN
dialogues.text: as they return the fire. In a moment a hot battle is raging, the ghostly forms of the armored vehicles momentarily illuminated by the muzzle flashes.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: Patton's jeep, driven by Codman, appears in the distance, moves toward camera, As it negotiates a little bend in the road, Patton signals Codman to stop. They both get out, staring at the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: RIAD, (THEIR P.9.V.)
dialogues.text: In the gray silence of early dawn the devastation of last night's tank battle can be seen. An SS panzer detachment, an awesome collection of tanks, field guns, ambulances an trucks, lies scattered along the road, the vehicles dead and burned out. ‘two of the three American tanks can be seen, one blasted open, its insides still smoking. Patton and Codman move past camera into scene. They move forward without words, fascinated by the strange silent atmosphere of this killing ground.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON, (MOVING)
dialogues.text: as he surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vehicles and field pieces are blasted and charred. And everywhere -- in the vehicles, in the ditch, in the field beside it -- are the corpses of German soldiers. Dead men sit in trucks as if still driving. Wounded men, now dead, spill crazily out of an ambulance. A man sits upright at his field piece as though asleep.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: His eyes absorb every detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying on the ground beside an American tank are the bodie of several GIs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contimaing on, Patton suddenly comes across the big quiet Captain we saw in his tank last night. Bone-tired, his eyes glazed and bloodshot with fatigue, he sits propped against the treads of a tank.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Were you in command here, Captain? Cont.  © 66 127 361 Cont. 382 fhe Captain looks up at Patton blankly, makes no effort t rise. He is almost too exhausted to speak.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Iwas in command... My tank platoon was supporting an infantry company. Tanks ran out of gas -- so we had to fight it out. We started eleven o'clock last nignt, finished a couple of hours ago. Patton looks up and notices that in the field nearby are American and German dead, seemingly in each other's embra

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: This morning the fighting was hand- to-hand. Patton looks at the Captain, then suddenly takes the exhausted face in his hands and kisses the man on the forehead. Cawera follows Patton as he moves off, deeply moved, and continues to explore the strange, silent battl ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He proceeds a few more steps, totally immersed in the eerie scene. Then he pauses, pulls out of his pocket an old folded Michelin touring map, glances at it fondly.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You know, Cod -- it always comes to me at nicht. Starts out as a headache... I teke an aspirin and it turns into a dream. Then I've got it. (inner excitement mounting) Right now the whole Nazi Reich is mine for the taking... Think of it! I was almost sent home in disgrace -- and now I have precisely the right instrument at precisely the right moment in history -- (shows the map to Codman, his finger pointing for emphasis) -- at exactly the right place.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (looking where Patton's finger points) The Sear? Cont.  382 Cont. 128

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (nodding) This will change soon, like a planet spinning off into the universe. Such a moment won't come again for a thousand years. And ell I need is a few miserable gallons of gasoline. (tapping the map again with his finger) Right now, this is the weak spot. Ten days and I could be in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: What about the fortifications at Verdun and Metz?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Fixed fortifications are man's monument to stupidity. (confidently) When mountain ranges and oceans can be overcome, anything built by man can be overcome. (smiling, like a boy with a riddle) You know how I know they're finished out there? Codman shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The carts. They're using carts to lug their supplies and wounded. Camera moves close to Patton and, for a moment, we almost can remember the spectacle he describes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: In my dream I saw the carts. They kept buzzing around in my head and I couldn't figure out why. Then I remembered: the nightmare in the snow -- the endless, agonizing retreat from Moscow. God the cold! The wounded, and what was left of the supplies, were thrown into carts. Napoleon was finished. No color left, not even the red of blood. Only snow. He pauses for a long moment, looking at the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with deep inner excitement) Just look at that, Codman. Compared tc war, all other forms of human endeavor shrink to insignificance.  129

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These shots show French troops entering Paris, with the wildly cheering populace out to greet them. The Parisians swarm all over the soldiers, kissing them, giving them food and wine, etc. Scenes of absolute triumph and unrestrained joy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Paris is liberated -- and French troops lead the way! The Allies march into the historic city after four years of Nazi occupation. The hard-fighting French Second Armored Division under Major General Jacques Leclerc, temporarily detached from Patton's Third Army, gets a welcome they will never forget as they enter their beloved Paris!

dialogues.speaker: H.
dialogues.text: Oo NARRATOR'S VOICE (o-s-) In a powerful drive to the north British General Montgomery cuts off and bypasses the French coastal towns of Boulogne, Calais and Dunkirk -- pushing on to capture the vital Belgian port of Antwerp.

dialogues.speaker: O.S.
dialogues.text: roenites a main body of Patton's army, resupplied now and rolling like a juggernaut, is slashing toward the Saar. Nazi resistance appears to be crumbling, and it seems that nothing can stop our troops from driving on into the heart of Germany. NOTE: END OF NEWSREEL. 66  394- 397 398 399 400 4o1 4o2 403 130

dialogues.speaker: THE ARDENNES FOREST
dialogues.text: The screen is made opaque by a whirling blizzard. The music is cold, strange, frightening. Out of the mist and snow a ghostly formation of giant German tanks looms up, lunging forward. A roadside sign -- ST. VITH. German mechanized artillery races forward past a sign reading MALMEDY. German infantry slogging on behind protecting tanks. Another sign: HOUFFALIZE.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWY FOREST
dialogues.text: Americen infantry, under a heavy mortar barrage, are ordered by a platoon commander to relinquish their positi They break and run as Nazi tanks loom up on the forest ro

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Showing burning American vehicles, spilled-out American dead.

dialogues.speaker: ROADSIDE
dialogues.text: as German tanks roar past, moving forward. Camera pans across a still-smoldering American personnel carrier, bes which is a sign in English: NO PARKING.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Patton is at work with his maps. Artillery can be heard i b.g. as Davenport enters. It is windy and storming outsid Willy is sleeping on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: Sir, General Bradley on your line. Patton picks up the phone, speaks with unbounded enthusia

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Brad -- I've got a bridgehead across the Saar! I'm on my way into Germany!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (into phone, firmly) Wait a minute, George. We've got some trouble up north. I want you to transfer 10th Armored to Middleton's VIII Corps right away. “CLOSE SHOT - PATTON

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (roaring) Brad, you can't do that to me -- !  4ok 405

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (with quiet but unshakable authority) I don't have time to argue. There's a lot of enemy activity up around the Ardennes. Don't know yet how serious it is, but Ike wants us to meet with Beetle Smith tomorrow at Verdun. Be there at eleven hundred.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (he hangs up, turns to Davenport} Get Bell in here. We may have a new ball game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This map takes in Patton's present positions as well as Luxembourg and the Ardennes. Camera pulls back to reveal Patton and Bell.

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: (indicating paper in his hand) The last intercept indicated the German troop concentration north of Trier is breaking up. After that they went on radio silence. (pointedly) . When we put our units on radio silence, it means we're going to move.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (computing the possibilities) There's absolutely no reason for us to assume the Germans are mounting a major offensive.. The weather is awful. Their supplies are low. And the German army hasn't mounted a winter attack since Frederick the Great...Therefore, I believe that's exactly what they're going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Third Army staff is gathered, listening to Patton. Willy is seated in a chair with the others.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (using map) I want you to start making contingency plans for pulling out of our eastward attack, changing direction ninety degrees and moving up to Luxembourg. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 132 B-405 Cont. 406 407 PATTON (Cont.) (noticing the glances being exchanged) Don't look so stunned, gentlemen. Plan for three possible axes of attack: from Diekirch due north; from Arlon toward Bastogne; from Neufchateau against the German left flank.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A sign on the building designates it as EAGLE MAIN. Sentries stand outside the snow-swept building as Patton is driven up in a jeep. He gets out, hurries on inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT, DAY ROOM IN FRENCH BARRACKS
dialogues.text: It is a fairly barren room with a heavy table, around whi are seated, in addition to Bradley and Patton, Smitn, Ted de Guingand and a few SHAEF officers. There is @ map on a easel showing the deep penetration of the allied lines al CT front, and at the map is a British BRIGADIER GENERAL.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL
dialogues.text: We've identified four German armies -- the Seventh, the Fifth Panzer, the Sixth SS Panzer and the Fifteenth. They've hit us with twenty-six divisions. They overran two regiments of the 106th Division, and seventy-five hundred of our men were forced to surrender...Qur ° immediate concern is that Von Runstedt has the 10lst Airborne trapped here at Bastogne --

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Bastogne, by the way, is the key to this entire area. If we can hold it, we can break up the German offensive. If they take it, we're in serious trouble. (looking to de Guingand and Patton) Ike wants to know if somebody can get up there and relieve the 101st before they're cut to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: DE GUINGAND
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there's nothing Field Marshal Montgomery can do -- not for some weeks at any rate.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: George -- what about you? Cont.  407 Cont. There is 133

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I can attack with three divisions in forty-eight hours. a stir and a shifting of chairs, surprise and skepticism on every face. They eye 66

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: I'd give myself some leeway if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (a little impatient) Ike wants a realistic estimate, George ... YouTre in the middle of a fight now. And it's over a hundred miles to Bastogne.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with quiet assurance) My staff's already working out the details. him in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Frankly, I don't see how it's possible. Not in this kind of weather.

dialogues.speaker: DE GUINGAND
dialogues.text: I should think first of all, you'd want to fall back and regroup.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (enjoying this) Not me, Freddy. I don't like to pay twice for the same real estate.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDER
dialogues.text: What about your men? You can't pull them out of the line, cart them off a hundred miles, and expect them to attack without rest!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I trained those men, Arthur. They'll do anything I tell them to do.

dialogues.speaker: DE GUINGAND
dialogues.text: (drily needling) We hadn't rezlized you were so popular with your troops, General. Cont.  66 134 407 Cont.1 408 409 410

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm not. They'll do it because they're good soldiers... And because they know, as I do, that we can still lose this war!

dialogues.speaker: DE GUINGAND
dialogues.text: I think I can speak, sir, for Field Marshal Montgomery. He'd say you're demanding the impossible of your men.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with a taunting smile) Sure he would. He doesn't realize that's what we're in business for!

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THIRD ARMY TANK PARK
dialogues.text: There is heavy snow on the ground. Everywhere there is feverish preparation for an armored attack. A tank crew is busy slapping white paint on the side of its tank. Another tank, already whitened, is moving out fast. MED, ‘SHOT The last member of a tank crew sloshes white paint on ae helmet and mounts up as the tank pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two tanks are parked beside the farmhouse. GIs are tossin sheets down from a second-story window to men below, who are ripping them up for camouflage suits, cutting armhole etc. One tank crew, already fitted out, mounts up and zooms off.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: A Third Army armored outfit roars northward along the snow-Clogged road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A window of this office looks out upon an arched bridge. Moving over it is a never-ending stream of Third Army tanks, half-tracks and 2-1/2 ton trucks. Bradley and Hansen are watching through the window.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: If they get there in time it'll be a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (quietly) George is pretty good at miracles.  413 4 445 417- 4ig 420 421- 423 66 135

dialogues.speaker: ICY ROADSIDE
dialogues.text: Artillery fire can be heard as Third Army trucks pull up infantrymen pile out, deploying on both sides of the roac

dialogues.speaker: INFANTRY ADVANCING
dialogues.text: German tanks appear, their guns firing at the advancing American infantry. Two of the tanks fire searing bursts from the flame-throwers, a frightening crimson tongue against the white snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American tank, buttoned up, advances down the street scattering cows, pigs and chickens. It is taking heavy fire from @ building. The tank rumbles up to the building pokes the muzzle of its gun through a window and blasts away, silencing the opposition.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patton, Davenport and Codman are in @ jeep watching a mechanized outfit roll by on the snow-covered icy road. It's an impressive sight: self-propelled guns, rocket launchers, heavy equipment of all kinds and men --~ hundreds of men -- rolling forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of the soldiers manning this equipment -- the men i the_trucks, on the self-propelled guns, in the armored personnel carriers. They are young -- but they have the look of veteran soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON, DAVENPORT AND CODMAN
dialogues.text: Patton watches as his men pass by.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Here's where the training and discipline pays off. Wkat other outfit could pull out of a winter battle, move a hundred miles, and go into a major attack with no sleep, no rest, not even hot food? (with a deep sense of pride and glory) God, I'm proud of these men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faces of individual GIs: A tank commander in his turret, face seared by the icy wind. A soldier in a 2-1/2 ton truck, gouging frozen K ration out of a tin with a trench knife. Infantrymen marching against the wintry blast.  66 ea 4a5 426 427 428 429 136

dialogues.speaker: TANK
dialogues.text: Chalked on its side is the legend: HEY, IKE - WANT TO WIN

dialogues.speaker: ARMORED PERSONNEL CARRIER
dialogues.text: In chalk, on its side: HOME ALIVE IN '45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COLONEL commanding an armored regiment is watching fr his radio-equipped jeep as MPs sort out the traffic. Patton drives up, and the Colonel gets out of his jeep wi a piece of paper, comes over to Patton and salutes. The sound of artillery fire can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (indicating message in his hand) Sir, General McAuliffe's turned down a German surrender demand!.... You know what he said?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOLONEL
dialogues.text: He said, 'Nuts!'

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with a broad grin of admiration Keep moving, Colonel! A man thet eloquent has to be saved!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy enemy shells are bursting all around as the GIs advance through the snow-shrouded forest. Air bursts clip the tops of huge fir trees and they come tumbling to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EDGE OF FOREST
dialogues.text: The Gis emerge from the woods, firing as they go. In the distance, we can see German troops who have broken and ar retreating. our  430 431 432 433 43h 435 66 137

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: A German tank outfit is retreating down the snowy, muddy road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American armored unit is in hot pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: ROADSIDE
dialogues.text: A German noncom pushes the plunger on a detonator.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Shooting over American tanks in f.g., with German tanks disappearing in distance. Suddenly, in a series of explosions starting at the far end and working forward, trees are blasted in such a way that they fall from both sides of the road across the roadway. The lead American tank swings abruptly and moves off the road, signaling other tanks to follow.

dialogues.speaker: BESIDE ROAD
dialogues.text: Melting snow has created a sea of mud and the tanks, trying to circumvent the roadblock, are slewing around in hopeless confusion.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Members of the Third Army staff are busy at phones or wit paper work -- Carver, Bell, Davenport, Codman, etc. There a sense of tension and urgency. Willy is present. And Patton is the center of the activity. Cont.  66 435 Cont. He hangs 138

dialogues.speaker: BELL
dialogues.text: Sir, Von Rundstedt's thrown another panzer division against Bastogne. 101st Airborne is hanging on by their fingernails.”

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Air cover -- that's what we need. Twenty-four hours of decent weather and we could make it.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: {handing Patton a phone) General Mason, sir -~

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mace -- we're short of foot soldiers. I want you to cannibalize your anti- tank units and turn them into rifle- men. Yes -- every damn one you can find! up. Davenport has.entered, snow-covered.

dialogues.speaker: DAVENPORT
dialogues.text: (grimy) General -- I just got the weather report for tomorrow. More snow.

dialogues.speaker: CARVER
dialogues.text: There goes our air cover. Sir, we may have to pull up and wait for better weather.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: There are brave men dying up there. I won't wait for one hour or one minute. We keep moving -- is that clear?! (after a suitable pause) We attack all night and we attack tomorrow morrming. If we are not victorious, let no one come back alive. He nods curtiy in dismissal, turns to his maps. The staff members greet this overblown statement with an exchange of uncertain glances, edge their way to the door, leaving Patton alone with Codman. Codman eyes him, decides to venture the question.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: You know something, General? Sometimes they can't tell when you're acting and when you're nov. Cont.  139 435 Cont.l

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (with a sly and private smile) It isn't important for them to know. Itts only important for me to know. The Third Army CHAPLAIN, a Colonel, enters, wearing a snow-flecked heavy combat jacket.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: You wanted to see m, General? PaTTON Chaplain, I'm sick and tired of Third Army trying to fight Germans, the Supreme Command, no gasoline -- and now this ungodly weather!... I want a prayer. A weather prayer.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Weather prayer, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Let's see if you can't get God working on our side in this thing.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: It's going to take a pretty thick rug for that kind of praying.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I don't care if it takes a flying carpet.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: Itm not sure, General, how that would be received -- a prayer for good weather so we can kill our fellowman.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I can assure you, because of my intimate relations with the Almighty, that if you write a good prayer, we'll have good weather. (curtly, glancing at his waveh) I'll expect that prayer within an hour.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPLAIN
dialogues.text: {all but gulping) Yes, sir. 66  66 4.36 437 438 439 ha 140

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Patton is moving through the snow and sleet of the bitter wintry night. Armored vehicles of every description are roaring past him, headed north.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON, (MOVING)
dialogues.text: He has a piece of paper in his hand. He looks up from the paper, speaks as he walks along, with great intensity.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: ‘Almighty and most merciful Father... we humbly beseech Thee, of Thy great goodness, to restrain these immoderate rains with which we have had to contend...!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American tanks drive forward through a blizzard of snow. An occasional muzzle blast sears the night.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) : ..-Grant us fair weather for Battle. Graciously hearken to us as soldiers who call upon Thee that...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freezing infantrymen move through the forest, with artill shells exploding all around them. Soms men drop and do not rise again.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) .+.'armed with Thy power, we may advance from victory to victory...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot of the treetops as @ tree burst hits. The snow- covered top of a giant tree is sheared off and drops heavily to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) ',..and crush the oppression and wickedness of our enemies...!

dialogues.speaker: WOUNDED GI
dialogues.text: A hollow-eyed dogface, his left arm shattered, staggers forward mechanically, oblivious to cold and blood and pai

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: {o.s.) ',,.and establish Thy justice among men and nations. Amen.'  66 LWh3 uhs Ube Lh? 450 ks. k52~ 455 456 14

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN HEAVY BOMBERS
dialogues.text: The flight of bombers flies by overhead against the sudde bright blue of a clear winter sky.

dialogues.speaker: XT. PATTON'S COMMAND POST, (AT NANCY)
dialogues.text: Patton, Davenport and Codman standing outside the CP, staring up at the aircraft with happy faces. Willy is with them.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (euphoric) Weather's perfect!... Get me that Chaplain. He stands in good with the Lord and I want to decorate him! LONG SHOT - AMERICAN ARMORED COLUMN - Da¥ A spectacular shot of armor racing down a snow-covered ro at top speed, with a flight of P-51s flying cover in the brilliant blue sky overhead. CLOSE SHOT - 155MM SHELL - DaY On the shell is chalked: MERRY XMAS FROM

dialogues.speaker: 101ST AIRBORNE
dialogues.text: The shell is slammed into the breech and the breech block locked.

dialogues.speaker: PERIMETER
dialogues.text: Man firing from snow-covered foxhole, featuring his 101st Airborne shoulder patch. Man in double foxhole wrapping burlap around his frost- pitten feet, tears of pain running down his cheeks - and another GI is forcing a cigarette between his lips. Other soldiers firing at advancing Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they fight desperately to hold off the attackers: Cooks and bakers, wearing their white uniforms over their ODs, firing at the Germans. Negro Quartermaster troops, firing carbines, bazookas, even hurling grenades.

dialogues.speaker: GERMANS
dialogues.text: The attackers advance inexorably. Two tanks appear, in support of the German infantry, firing into the positions of the defenders.  66 457 458 459 4.60 461 462 467- 469 12

dialogues.speaker: AMSRICAN ANTI-TANK GUN
dialogues.text: The half-frozen crew loads and fires as fast as possible.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: Ignoring the anti-tank fire, the German fires his gun.

dialogues.speaker: ANTI-TANK POSITION
dialogues.text: The gun takes a direct hit, the crew is destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American defenders can't stand up against the over- wWhelming odds and they start pulling back behind a wail near the town.

dialogues.speaker: THE ADVANCING GERMANS
dialogues.text: Suddenly, out of nowhere, Third Army tanks appear from th woods, flanking the German advance. They roar into action knocking out the two German tanks and delivering a wither fire into the German infantry, which breaks and runs, lea heavy casualties. An American armored spearhead follows t lead tanks, with infantrymen clinging to the sides of the Shermans, tearing in toward the beleaguered town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the defenders rise up, scarcely able to believe what they see.

dialogues.speaker: GI
dialogues.text: It's the Third Army! Old Georgie did it! He did it! Wild with joy, a GI pokes the motionless man next to him. Like a figure of stone, the dead man falls against the wall on his face, frozen solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ragged, bone-weary and desperate defenders of Bastogn creep out in stunned and half-hysterical amazement. They throw their arms around the Third Army GIs who slide down off*the tanks and embrace them wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc. Showing mammoth preparations for the Rhine crossing. British troops, huge stockpiles of ammunition, trucks, tanks, bulldozers, assault craft, etc. Anda shot of Winston Churchill, Cont.  oO 143 467- Cont. 469

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British Field Marshal Montgomery, with three Allied armies, has assembled the greatest military buildup since D-day in order to assault what Winston Churchill has called 'the greatest water obstacle in Western Europe'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton is speaking into a phone, and he is beside himself with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Helio, Brad? I'm across!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be damned. You mean across the Rhine?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Yes! J sneaked a division over last night. Dome a favor and make the announcement, will you? I want the world to know Third Army did it before Monty could even get started!

dialogues.speaker: F 5
dialogues.text: Russian and American troops meeting at Torgau. They exchange greetings, cigarettes, embraces. They clown for the cameramen, trying on each other's caps, etc.

dialogues.speaker: HARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: {o.s.) Russian and American soldiers, meeting for the first time in World War II, enact a scene of wild celebration as the two allied armies meet at the Elbe River, deep inside Nazi Germany.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: This usually crowded, bustling room is silent now and unoccupied -- silent except for the nearby thunder of Cont.  66 Uy 473 Cont. The is Russian siege guns -- unoccupied except for the two lonel figures of Jodl and Steiger, The deserted maps, the silen teletypes give the huge room a quality of palpable defeat There is fallen plaster from nearby shellbursts. Jodi, literal-minded even in chaos, works feverishly to destroy classified material. Steiger is quite calmly glancing through a pile of Patton material on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Get a move on, Steiger. I want everything destroyed. Papers, maps, everything.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: (with a grim, private smile} Everything will be destroyed, General -- that I can promise you. There is a particularly loud, close burst of artillery fire, and the point of Steiger's remark is not entirely lost on Jodi.

dialogues.speaker: JODL
dialogues.text: {as plester dust filters down) I'll never let those Russian barbarians take me! I'll die by my own hand first -- as the Fuehrer did in his bunker! His eye falls on a picture of Hitler on the wall, its frame hanging crooked from the shelling. Steiger, who seems strangely unmoved, uninvolved, is looking at a photograph of Patton he has come across.

dialogues.speaker: STEIGER
dialogues.text: (studying the picture with quiet objectivity) He, too, will be destroyed. The absence of war will kill hin. (thoughtfully ) The pure warrior -- a magnificent anachronism.  66 480 1s INT. HOTEL DINING ROOM ~ NIGHT ‘ (FORMERLY SCENE ),82) The room has been cleared of tables and elaborately decorated with Russian and American flags for a joint reception of high-ranking American and Russian officers. A balalaika band of Russian soldiers is playing. There are dancers and acrobats performing. Patton stands talking with Codman and Davenport as a RUSSIAN GENERAL, complete with medals, approaches with a civilian INTERPRETER. The Russian smiles affably and Patton scowls ferociously as the Interpreter speaks to him in English. A waiter appears, bearing a tray on which are two stiff drinks.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir -- General Katkov wishes to know if you will join him for a drink to celebrate the German surrender. Cont.  66 146 480 Cont. 482

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You tell the General I don't care to drink with him or any other Russian gonuvabitch. Both Davenport and Codman react and the Interpreter stares at him in open-mouthed disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Sir, I - I cannot tell the General thet --

dialogues.speaker: PATION
dialogues.text: (firmly) You tell him word for word -- and don't leave out the'sonuvabitch'! The Interpreter turns, red-faced and apologetic, and repe Patton's reply in Russian, The General flushes angrily, glares at Patton and for a moment an international explos seems likely, Then, controlling himself, the Russian gets off a couple of quick sentences to the Interpreter in Russian.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: (to Patton) The General says he thinks you are a sonuvabitch, too.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {suddenly laughing) Okay -- I'll drink to that. One sonuvabitch to another. The two men take the glasses off the tray and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BAD TOLZ) - DAY - (FORMERLY SCENE 480)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of CORRESPONDENTS is gathered in the office questioning Patton. Davenport and Codman are also present

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: General, is it true that President Roosevelt, before he died, promised you a combat command in the Pacific?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (his personal . disappointment apperent} Yes, he did. But once he was gone, there wasn't a chance. (with a wry smile) MacArthur didn't want me out there. Cont.  ®@ 66 481 Cont. 147

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: We've been told about these wonder - weapons the Germans were working on. Long-range rockets, push-button bombing, weapons that don't need soldiers --

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (a depressed man) Wonder weapons! God, I can't see the wonder in them. Killing without heroics, Nothing is glorified, nothing is reaffirmed. No heroes, no cowards, no troops... (pause) No generals. Only those who are left alive and those who are left... dead. I'm glad I won't live to see it.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: It's been pointed out, General, that you're stiil using former Nazis in key positions, despite the official de-Nazification policy.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (testily) If I'm supplied with trained personnel, I'il get rid of the Nazis. Till then, I'll use the people who know how to run the railroads and keep the telephones working.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (apparently casually) After all, General, didn't most ordinary Nazis join the party in about the same way Americans become Republicans or Democrats?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Yes. That's about it. Codman and Harkins react with instant apprehension. The Correspondents exchange glances, scribble furiously.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (baiting him) You do agree, don't you, that our national policy should be made by civilians and not by the military? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The politicians never let us finish awar. They always stop short -- leave us with another war to be fought.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (with a shrewd smile) You thinking about cur Russian allies, General? Patton smiles blandly, doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: Sir, did you say if you found your army between the Germans and the Russians, you'd attack in both directions?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: No, I didn't say that -- but I wish T had. The reporters are scribbling again. our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We reveal that an artist is working on the portrait. Patt wears his seven rows of ribbons, his four stars, his ivor handled pistols. Camera pans to Patton himself in the exact uniform and pose. But he looks different from the painting; he looks tired and worn, his hair sparser, his eyes dark, his face pale.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: (entering) Sir, ‘there's a call on your line from Supreme Headquarters. General Smith. As Patton crosses and picks up the phone, Codman motions the artist out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: GEIERAL SMITH AT PHONE
dialogues.text: His face is stern, his voice cuts like a lash.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Ike is furious! How could you possibly compare Democrats and épublicans to the Nazi party?... And this statement that you refuse to de-Nazify has everybody screaming -- the British, the Russians, everybody.  66 485 486 487 488 489 14g

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (impatiently) The hell with those Mongoloid Russians. We let them take Berlin and Prague and God knows what else. Are we going to let them dictate policy, too?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool, George. The war in Europe is over. Washington dictates policy.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: His personal prejudice and his burning aversion to the prospect of a peacetime existence combine to make him pre frenetic.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: The war shouldn't be over! And we should stop pussyfooting about the goddamn Russians. We'll have to fight them sooner or later. Why not do it now while we have an army to do it with? Instead of disarming these German troops, we should get them to help us fight the damn Bolsheviks!

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: George, you'd better shup up. This line may be tapped.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn if it is! You want to know something, Beetle? Up till now we've been fighting the wrong people! (in a manic phase, his eyes burn with excitement) Look -- you and Ike don't have to get involved if you're so damn soft about it. Just leave it to me. In ten days I can have us at war with those sonsuvbitches and make it look like they started it.  66 490 gz 492

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (genuinely frightened and appalled) You're mad, George -- you're absolutely out of your mind!

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: {almost frenziedly) I'm no diplomat. I'm a combat soldier -- and that's what these jokers understand. You get Ike to give me the word and I'll kick their behinds back into Russia where they belong -- |

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: His face grim, he quietly and deliberately hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Stunned, Patton hangs up, stares silently at Godman, who has been watching him.

dialogues.speaker: CODMAN
dialogues.text: Shall I call the artist back, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PATTON -
dialogues.text: Hell with it... Nobody wants to look at a picture of me. I'm mad, didn't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: BED
dialogues.text: Laid out on the bed with meticulous care is Patton's elaborate blouse, with all its colorful decorations. Also the pistol belt, the shiny helmet, the riding breeches and, beside the bed, the highly polished boots. Camera pulls back to reveal Patton dressing before a mirror, He wears a pair of plain GI trousers, and Meeks is helping him into a simple Eisenhower jacket totally devoid of decorations, bearing only the four stars of his rank. As Patton studies his unfamiliar image in the mirro he seems, for the first time, to have aged. His eyes look tired and his face is pale.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: (studying Patton's appearance without enthusiasm) General -- you sure you want to wear that uniform? Gont.  66 151 493 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: A-493
dialogues.text: you, 495

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (deeply apprehensive, he doesn't hear) General Eisenhower's treated me very fairly -- but when he sends for me, it usually means troudile. Patton has buttoned up the unadorned jacket, and Meeks is not at all pleased with the result.

dialogues.speaker: MEEKS
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) That makes you look -- I don't know -- kinda naked.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You know something, George? That's the way I feel.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Featured is an impressive door (presumably in Buckingham Palace) with a liveried doorman outside it. Waiting nearb on an antique settee is Montgomery. He is in his most impressive military finery -- medals, honours, etc. -- much more elaborately dressed than we have ever seen him. The door opens and a GUARDS OFFICER, in dress uniform, steps outside, bows sligitly as he speaks to Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Field Marshal -~ His Majesty is prepared to receive the next Commander of the Imperial General Staff. Montgomery rises and goes on into the open door, which is held for him and the Guards Officer by the doorman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is decorated with elaborate flags, plaques, SHA insignia. A group of five or six CORRESPONDENTS waits impatiently in the anteroom. Several faces are recognizab as having been,at the press conference in Patton's Bad To office. Camera moves into office door, on which is a sign GENERAL EISENHOWER. The door opens and Patton comes out. His eyes are lifeless and he appears shaken, utterly drai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Correspondents are stunned by his appearance. As he closes the door and moves off, one of them steps forward speak to him. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: One moment, General -- Uncharacteristically affected by the shock Patton has sustained, two of the Correspondents take hold of their colleague and pull him back. They watch as Patton, oblivious, moves across the room like a sleepwalker and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: INT, PATTON'S HEADQUARTERS, (IN BAD TOLZ)
dialogues.text: Lined up in the room are Carver, Davenport, Bell, Codman, Stiller and several enlisted men, including Sergeant Meek and Patton's driver. Camera follows as Patton moves down the line shaking each man's hand in turn. The men try to remain at blank-faced attention, but most eyes are misty. At the end of the line, Patton turns to face the group and there are tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen -- all good things must come to an end -- (he continues with difficulty) The best thing that has come to me in my life is the honor and privilege of having commanded the Third Army. Good-bye -- and God bless you. He turns quickly and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: DA
dialogues.text: It is a gray winter day, the sun blotted out by an over- cast that mutes all colors. There is snow on the ground and the streets are icy. Patton comes out of the building alone, deep in his own unhappiness, and is surprised to find himself facing Bradley, who has actually been waitin for him. Bradley now wears four stars.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: I've been relieved, Brad. They've taken Third Army away from me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: I know. (he tries to sound casual) I thought we might have dinner together tonight --

dialogues.speaker: ATTON
dialogues.text: (touched and grateful) That's damn thoughtful, Brad, and I appreciate it. (gesturing toward his jeep across the street) Right now I'm going to take Willy for a ee Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 153 97 Cont. 498 99 Bradley joins him as they move across the sidewalk. A man is unhitching a team of oxen from a cart parked in the street. As the oxen are removed, the cart starts rolling down the icy street. Gathering speed, it is headed straig for Patton as he steps off the curb.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George -- look out) Patton manages to leap out of the way just in time, and t cart crashes to a stop against a parked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Patton gets up, brushes the snow off his uniform.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (wryly) After all I've been through, imagine me getting killed by an oxcart. Bradley grins. Patton continues moodily.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: You know -- there's only one proper end for a professional soldier. A quick. death inflicted by the last bullet of the last battle. They move on across the street, camera panning with them.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON AND BRADLEY, (TRUCKING)
dialogues.text: They walk down the sidewalk on the opposite side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: In our drive across Europe Third Army liberated twelve thousand cities and towns -- inflicted a million and a half enemy casualties.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I have a-feeling that from now on just being a good soldier won't be enough. I'm afraid we're going to have to be dislomats and administrators, too.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: (growling his disgust) God help us! Cont.  66 154 499 Cont. 500 501 502 They have come to Patton's parked jeep where his driver is holding Willy. He hands the leash to Patton, who takes the dog.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: George -- I just want to say one thing -- you've done a magnificent job here in Europe... I think that soldier you slapped back in Sicily did more to win the war than any other private in the Army. Overwhelmed by Bradley's generosity, Patton's face breaks into @ big, sudden grin.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON
dialogues.text: See you for dinner. He turns away, leading Willy with him, and Bradley watche him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Patton moves down a short side street, beyond which we can see open snow-covered countryside. An enormous windmill turns slowly. In f.g., a group of GIs is busy working, hauling supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For over a thousand years, Roman conquerors returning from the wars enjoyed the honor of a triumph, a tumultuous parade.

dialogues.speaker: SNOWY COUNTRYSIDE
dialogues.text: As Patton and Willy walk together toward the ice-covered windmill, stark against the snow. Its creaking sound combined with the sound of the wind, produces a strange effect.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) In the procession came trumpeters and musicians and strange animals from the conquered territories...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patton's figure stands out against the otherwise absolute white snowscape. The windmill, with its eerie sound, is still in frame. Cont.  155 502 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — ( PATTON'S VOICE o.s. .., together with carts laden with treasure and captured armaments.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON WALKING
dialogues.text: 504 505 66 deep in thought, his eyes fixed on some middle-distance of his own.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: {o.s. The conqueror rode in a triumphal chariot, the dazed prisoners walking in chains before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distant figure of Patton, headed toward the creaking windmill, is tiny against the vast expanse of snow.

dialogues.speaker: PATTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s8.) . Sometimes his children, robed in white, stood with him in the chariot, or rode the trace horses... A slave stood behind the conqueror, holding & golden crown and whispering in his ear a warning that all glory is fleeting... The figure of Patton has disappeared -~- and there is onl the ice-covered windmill and the whiteness of the snow.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.8.) Within a few weeks, George Patton died of injuries received when his staff car collided with a truck near the German city of Mannheim.
